item.title: Trump pardons Giuliani and allies accused of trying to subvert 2020 election ‚Äì latest updates
item.description:
Directive could prevent future administrations from prosecuting more than 70 people named

US forces struck two more alleged drug trafficking boats off the coast of South America, killing six people, the Trump administration‚Äôs defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, has said.

The US began carrying out such strikes ‚Äì which some experts say amount to extrajudicial killings even if they target known traffickers ‚Äì in early September, taking aim at vessels in the Caribbean and eastern Pacific.

Continue reading...

item.title: Hegseth says six people killed in two new US attacks on alleged drug boats
item.description:
US defense secretary says without providing evidence that dead from strikes in eastern Pacific were ‚Äònarco-terrorists‚Äô

US forces struck two more alleged drug trafficking boats off the coast of South America, killing six people, the Trump administration‚Äôs defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, has said.

The US began carrying out such strikes ‚Äì which some experts say amount to extrajudicial killings even if they target known traffickers ‚Äì in early September, taking aim at vessels in the Caribbean and eastern Pacific. More than 70 people have been killed in the strikes so far.

item.title: A potential end to the government shutdown
item.description: There‚Äôs movement in Washington toward ending the government shutdown. The Senate held a procedural vote yesterday. Seven Democrats and one independent senator voted yes with Republicans, which finally broke the logjam and will allow final votes on a bill to reopen the government. It's progress, but there's still potential for derailment. Plus, New Mexico is offering free universal child care starting this month. We'll hear what that means for one family.
item.source:markdown: There‚Äôs movement in Washington toward ending the government shutdown. The Senate held a procedural vote yesterday. Seven Democrats and one independent senator voted yes with Republicans, which finally broke the logjam and will allow final votes on a bill to reopen the government. It's progress, but there's still potential for derailment. Plus, New Mexico is offering free universal child care starting this month. We'll hear what that means for one family.

item.title: How could Zohran Mamdani pay for his bold agenda for New York? We broke it down
item.description:
A look at the realities the mayor-elect will face to pay for his progressive policies ‚Äì and whose support he needs

  • Who is Zohran Mamdani, New York‚Äôs democratic socialist new mayor?

Bold promises to make the city more affordable propelled New York City mayor-elect and democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani to his unlikely win on Tuesday. Among them: free buses, universal childcare and a massive expansion in low-cost housing.

But making the city more affordable for residents is an expensive government task, one many economists and politicians to Mamdani‚Äôs right say he faces too many obstacles to meaningfully deliver on his signature ideas.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
A look at the realities the mayor-elect will face to pay for his progressive policies ‚Äì and whose support he needs
- [Who is Zohran Mamdani, New York‚Äôs democratic socialist new mayor?](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/04/zohran-mamdani-profile)
Bold [promises](https://www.zohranfornyc.com/platform) to make the city more affordable propelled [New York City](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/new-york) mayor-elect and democratic socialist [Zohran Mamdani](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/zohran-mamdani) to his unlikely [win](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/06/zohran-mamdani-campaign-new-york-democrats) on Tuesday. Among them: free buses, universal childcare and a massive expansion in low-cost housing.
But making the city [more affordable](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/04/zohran-mamdani-campaign-promises-analysis) for residents is an expensive government task, one many [economists](https://www.empirecenter.org/publications/parsing-the-impact-of-mamdanis-tax-hike-plans/) and politicians to Mamdani‚Äôs [right](https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2025/10/11/mamdani-free-buses-new-york-mayor/) say he [faces](https://www.cato.org/blog/mamdanis-wishful-thinking-tax-revenues) too many obstacles to meaningfully deliver on his signature ideas.

item.title: First Thing: Senate advances funding bill to end longest US government shutdown in history
item.description:
Amended package must be passed by the house and signed by the president. Plus, Volodymyr Zelenskyy on why he‚Äôs not afraid of Donald Trump

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

The Senate has made significant progress towards ending the longest US government shutdown in history, narrowly advancing a compromise bill to reauthorize funding and undo the layoffs of some employees.

What did the Democrats say about the bill? ‚ÄúThis healthcare crisis is so severe, so urgent, so devastating for families back home, that I cannot in good faith support this [resolution] that fails to address the healthcare crisis,‚Äù said Chuck Schumer, the Democratic majority leader.

What has the IDF said in response? In a written statement, the IDF said it ‚Äúremains committed to the rule of law and continues to operate in accordance with its legal and ethical obligations, despite the unprecedented operational complexity posed by Hamas‚Äôs systematic embedding within civilian infrastructure and its use of civilian sites for military purposes‚Äù.

Continue reading...

Good morning.
The Senate has made significant progress towards ending the longest US government shutdown in history, [narrowly advancing a compromise bill](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/10/us-government-shutdown-update-senate-funding-bill) to reauthorize funding and undo the layoffs of some employees.
**What did the Democrats say about the bill?** ‚ÄúThis healthcare crisis is so severe, so urgent, so devastating for families back home, that I cannot in good faith support this \[resolution\] that fails to address the healthcare crisis,‚Äù said Chuck Schumer, the Democratic majority leader.
**What has the IDF said in response?** In a written statement, the IDF said it ‚Äúremains committed to the rule of law and continues to operate in accordance with its legal and ethical obligations, despite the unprecedented operational complexity posed by Hamas‚Äôs systematic embedding within civilian infrastructure and its use of civilian sites for military purposes‚Äù.

item.title: Snap workers say Trump administration is ‚Äòusing country‚Äôs poorest as pawns‚Äô
item.description:
Employees providing assistance to recipients expressed fears on how lack of aid will affect those who need it most

When Stacy Smith, a government worker, showed up to work last Monday ‚Äì the first working day after food benefits lapsed, amid the ongoing federal shutdown ‚Äì she found a long line outside her office door. Elderly and disabled individuals desperately wanted answers.

Some had gone to buy groceries, not realizing that their usual benefits were unavailable.

Continue reading...

item.title: From floored to flawed: Does anyone want to win the Super Bowl this season?
item.description:
The NFL is built on parity. But this season the NFC only has a few contenders while even the best teams in the AFC have worrying flaws

No league sells parity like the NFL: it‚Äôs the entire brand. But through 10 weeks of this season, this isn‚Äôt a league that is equally balanced between the good, the bad and the mediocre. It‚Äôs one where most of the league is simply fine.

In the NFC, at least, there is some clarity. The Rams and Seahawks (both 7-2) look like the most complete teams in football, and secured blowout wins on Sunday. The 6-2 Eagles, despite their struggles, still have one of the most talented rosters in the league, likewise with the Packers (5-2-1). Even the Lions (6-3), who have been inconsistent along both lines of scrimmage and have been dealing with tension on their coaching staff, have proven they can hammer good teams. For all five, you can still easily put together a Super Bowl path.

Continue reading...

In the NFC, at least, there is some clarity. The Rams and Seahawks (both 7-2) look like the most complete teams in football, and secured blowout wins on Sunday. item.title: China eases export controls
item.description: From the BBC World Service: China has lifted export controls on computer chips that are vital to car production, marking an easing of trade tensions between China and the U.S. Automakers Volvo, VW, Ford, and Honda had all warned they could face severe supply chain disruptions if the ban wasn't overturned. China has also paused an export ban to the U.S. of some materials that are crucial in the semiconductor industry. Plus, a major cybercriminal reveals all.
item.source:markdown: _From the BBC World Service:_ China has lifted export controls on computer chips that are vital to car production, marking an easing of trade tensions between China and the U.S. Automakers Volvo, VW, Ford, and Honda had all warned they could face severe supply chain disruptions if the ban wasn't overturned. China has also paused an export ban to the U.S. of some materials that are crucial in the semiconductor industry. Plus, a major cybercriminal reveals all.

item.title: Medicaid head falsely claims $1bn is being spent on healthcare for ‚Äòillegal immigrants‚Äô, say experts
item.description:
Mehmet Oz made claim about audits, but experts say he misidentified routine administrative errors

The administrator for the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), Mehmet Oz, recently claimed that an audit revealed ‚Äúmore than $1bn of federal taxpayer dollars were being spent on funding Medicaid for illegal immigrants‚Äù, but experts say the audits were unrelated to immigration, and that rhetoric like this could make immigrant families ‚Äì regardless of legal status ‚Äì afraid to seek necessary medical care.

Leo Cuello, a research professor at Georgetown University‚Äôs Center for Children and Families, noted that he has not ‚Äúseen what this audit is‚Äù, but ‚Äúbased on the reporting, it appears that it is related to administrative errors in state claiming for matching funds, which is a relatively common occurrence, and which CMS monitors closely as they should‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: Resilience of Europe‚Äôs populist right carries warning for US Democrats
item.description:
As Democrats bask in electoral success the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Poland and Hungary offer a cautionary tale

In the afterglow of electoral triumph, hope springs renewed for Democrats confined to the frustrating impotence of political opposition.

Boosted by last week‚Äôs electoral wins in New York City, Virginia, New Jersey and elsewhere, as well as California‚Äôs affirmation of Proposition 50 allowing for congressional redistricting, party members suddenly feel able to dream that future elections may herald an escape route from the Donald Trump era.

Continue reading...

item.title: Chocolate's high tech and climate-friendly pivot
item.description:
Extreme weather caused by climate change is affecting agriculture and raising the cost of foods like coffee, olive oil and chocolate. Cocoa prices have been hitting record highs due to extreme rainfall, drought and heat. And some experts say most of the land used for cocoa production won‚Äôt be usable in the future.


Marketplace‚Äôs Amy Scott, host of our podcast "How We Survive," explores a new way tech entrepreneurs are making chocolate so that we can keep enjoying it for years to come.
item.source:markdown:

Cocoa prices have been hitting record highs due to extreme rainfall, drought and heat. And some experts say most of the land used for cocoa production won‚Äôt be usable in the future.
Marketplace‚Äôs Amy Scott, host of our podcast "How We Survive," explores a new way tech entrepreneurs are making chocolate so that we can keep enjoying it for years to come.

item.title: Coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, US study finds
item.description:
Trial‚Äôs findings go against common beliefs that people with atrial fibrillation should avoid caffeinated coffee

Drinking coffee may protect people against irregular heartbeats, despite the conventional wisdom to the contrary, according to a new study.

The Does Eliminating Coffee Avoid Fibrillation (Decaf) clinical trial found 200 patients with persistent irregular heartbeats had a ‚Äúsignificantly‚Äù lower risk of the condition recurring if they belonged to the study group that was allocated coffee consumption rather than the one abstaining from it ‚Äì 47% to 64%.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Trial‚Äôs findings go against common beliefs that people with atrial fibrillation should avoid caffeinated coffee
Drinking [coffee](https://www.theguardian.com/food/coffee) may protect people against irregular heartbeats, despite the conventional wisdom to the contrary, according to a new study.
The Does Eliminating Coffee Avoid Fibrillation (Decaf) clinical trial found 200 patients with persistent irregular heartbeats had a ‚Äúsignificantly‚Äù lower risk of the condition recurring if they belonged to the study group that was allocated coffee consumption rather than the one abstaining from it ‚Äì 47% to 64%.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/10/coffee-irregular-heartbeat-protection-study)

item.title: US president Donald Trump booed while attending Washington Commanders NFL game ‚Äì video
item.description:
Donald Trump became the first sitting US president in nearly 50 years to attend a regular-season NFL game when he dropped in on the Detroit Lions‚Äô win over the Washington Commanders on Sunday.

There were boos from large sections of fans, as well as scattered cheers, at the Commanders‚Äô Northwest Stadium when Trump was shown on the screens late in the first half ‚Äì and again when the president was introduced by the stadium announcer at half-time. The Washington DC area has strong Democratic support, while Trump‚Äôs cuts to the government have affected many workers in the vicinity of the Commanders‚Äô stadium. Sunday was not the first time Trump has received a hostile reception from a Washington sports crowd: he was greeted with ‚Äòlock him up‚Äô chants at the Washington Nationals‚Äô home stadium during the 2019 World Series.

  • Trump booed at Commanders NFL game before calling plays from Fox broadcast booth

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Donald Trump became the first sitting US president in nearly 50 years to attend a regular-season NFL game when he dropped in on the Detroit Lions‚Äô win over the [Washington Commanders](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/washington-commanders) on Sunday.
[There were boos](https://bsky.app/profile/acyn.bsky.social/post/3m5a7te2sva2q) from large sections of fans, as well as scattered cheers, at the Commanders‚Äô Northwest Stadium when Trump was shown on the screens late in the first half ‚Äì and again when the president was introduced by the stadium announcer at half-time. The Washington DC area has strong Democratic support, while Trump‚Äôs cuts to the government have affected many workers in the vicinity of the Commanders‚Äô stadium. Sunday was not the first time Trump has received a hostile reception from a Washington sports crowd: he was [greeted with ‚Äòlock him up‚Äô chants](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/oct/27/donald-trump-booed-world-series-lock-him-up-chants-baseball) at the Washington Nationals‚Äô home stadium during the 2019 World Series.
- [**Trump booed at Commanders NFL game before calling plays from Fox broadcast booth**](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/nov/09/donald-trump-commanders-nfl-game-fan-reaction)
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/video/2025/nov/10/us-president-donald-trump-booed-washington-commanders-nfl-game-video)

item.title: Trump news at a glance: eight Democrats join Republicans to advance funding bill
item.description:
Bill, a first step to ending the shutdown, will still need to be deliberated and passed by the Senate, and win approval in the house. Key US politics stories from 9 November at a glance

The first step toward ending the US government shutdown has been made after a handful of Democrats and dozens of Republicans voted to advance legislation in the Senate.

The funding bill will still need to be deliberated and passed by the Senate and approved by the House to end what has been the longest government shutdown in US history.

item.title: MLS playoffs: San Diego rout Timbers, advance to Western semifinals
item.description:
• Amahl Pellegrino and Anders Dreyer score braces

  • San Diego to face Minnesota United in next round

Amahl Pellegrino and Anders Dreyer each scored twice and San Diego FC eased into their first-ever Western Conference semi-final appearance with a 4-0 victory over the visiting Portland Timbers to clinch their first-round series on Sunday night.

Dreyer also picked up an assist on Pellegrino‚Äôs second goal while helping top-seeded San Diego secure a home semi-final against fourth-seeded Minnesota after the November international window.

Continue reading...

item.title: US Senate vote marks step towards ending federal shutdown
item.description:
Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reach

The US Senate on Sunday took a key vote on a bill that would end the record-setting federal government shutdown without extending the healthcare subsidies that Democrats have demanded.

Senators began voting on Sunday night to advance House-passed stopgap funding legislation that Senate majority leader John Thune said would be amended to combine another short-term spending measure with a package of three full-year appropriations bills.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reach
The [US Senate](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-senate) on Sunday took a key vote on a bill that would end the record-setting federal government shutdown without extending the healthcare subsidies that Democrats have demanded.
Senators began voting on Sunday night to advance House-passed stopgap funding legislation that Senate majority leader John Thune said would be amended to combine another short-term spending measure with a package of three full-year appropriations bills.

item.title: Growth in global demand for ‚Äògreen‚Äô office buildings slows amid Trump policies
item.description:
Fall reported by Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors as UN calls for accelerated action in buildings sector to meet global climate goals

The growth in global demand for ‚Äúgreen‚Äù office buildings has slowed after Donald Trump‚Äôs assault on environmental protection policies caused a slump in interest in the US, according to a survey of construction industry professionals.

Building occupiers and investors across North America and South America expressed significantly lower growth in demand for green commercial buildings, a shift that ‚Äúseems to be in response to a change in US policy focus‚Äù, according to a survey of members of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics). Reported demand across the rest of the world also fell, albeit not as sharply.

Continue reading...

Building occupiers and investors across North America and South America expressed significantly lower growth in demand for green commercial buildings, a shift that ‚Äúseems to be in response to a change in US policy focus‚Äù, according to a survey of members of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics). item.title: Trump booed at Commanders NFL game before calling plays from Fox broadcast booth
item.description:
• President greeted with jeers by many fans at game

  • Trump has appeared at several sports events this year

Donald Trump became the first sitting US president in nearly 50 years to attend a regular-season NFL game when he dropped in on the Detroit Lions‚Äô win over the Washington Commanders on Sunday.

There were boos from large sections of fans, as well as scattered cheers, at the Commanders‚Äô Northwest Stadium when Trump was shown on the screens late in the first half ‚Äì and again when the president was introduced by the stadium announcer at halftime. The Washington DC area has strong Democratic support, while Trump‚Äôs cuts to the government have affected many workers in the vicinity of the Commanders‚Äô stadium. Sunday was not the first time Trump has received a hostile reception from a Washington sports crowd: he was greeted with ‚Äòlock him up‚Äô chants at the Washington Nationals‚Äô home stadium during the 2019 World Series.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
- President greeted with jeers by many fans at game
- Trump has appeared at several sports events this year
Donald Trump became the first sitting US president in nearly 50 years to attend a regular-season NFL game when he dropped in on the Detroit Lions‚Äô win over the Washington Commanders on Sunday.
[There were boos](https://bsky.app/profile/acyn.bsky.social/post/3m5a7te2sva2q) from large sections of fans, as well as scattered cheers, at the Commanders‚Äô Northwest Stadium when Trump was shown on the screens late in the first half ‚Äì and again when the president was introduced by the stadium announcer at halftime. The Washington DC area has strong Democratic support, while Trump‚Äôs cuts to the government have affected many workers in the vicinity of the Commanders‚Äô stadium. Sunday was not the first time Trump has received a hostile reception from a Washington sports crowd: he was [greeted with ‚Äòlock him up‚Äô chants](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2019/oct/27/donald-trump-booed-world-series-lock-him-up-chants-baseball) at the Washington Nationals‚Äô home stadium during the 2019 World Series.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/nov/09/donald-trump-commanders-nfl-game-fan-reaction)

item.title: Trump shares false claim Obama earned $40m in ‚Äòroyalties‚Äô from Obamacare
item.description:
US president promoted fictional claim from satirical website that has been debunked repeatedly since 2017

Donald Trump promoted the false claim that Barack Obama has earned $40m in ‚Äúroyalties linked to Obamacare‚Äù in a post to his 11 million followers on Truth Social on Sunday.

The fictional claim that the former US president receives royalty payments for the use of his name to refer to the Affordable Care Act, which he signed into law in 2010, has been repeatedly debunked since at least 2017, when it was featured on America‚Äôs Last Line of Defense, a satirical website that produces fake news reports designed to generate engagement from outraged conservatives.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
US president promoted fictional claim from satirical website that has been debunked repeatedly since 2017
[Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) promoted the false claim that [Barack Obama](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/barack-obama) has earned $40m in ‚Äúroyalties linked to Obamacare‚Äù in a [post](https://truthsocial.com/@realDonaldTrump/posts/115520378078620283) to his 11 million followers on Truth Social on Sunday.
The fictional claim that the former US president receives royalty payments for the use of his name to refer to the Affordable Care Act, which he signed into law in 2010, has been repeatedly debunked [since at least 2017](https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/obamacare-royalties/), when it was featured on America‚Äôs Last Line of Defense, a satirical website that produces fake news reports designed to generate engagement from outraged conservatives.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/09/trump-obama-obamacare-royalties-claim)

item.title: NFL roundup: Dolphins shock Bills as Texans stage record comeback against Jags
item.description:
• Miami end seven-game losing streak against Buffalo

  • Houston score 26 points in final quarter to secure win

Tua Tagovailoa threw for 173 yards and two touchdowns, De‚ÄôVon Achane added a pair of rushing scores and the Miami Dolphins beat the Buffalo Bills to end a seven-game losing streak against their AFC East rivals. The Bills (6-3) had not lost to Miami (3-7) since Week 3 of the 2022 season but came out flat on Sunday.

Achane finished with 225 scrimmage yards and fourth-quarter touchdowns of 59 and 35 yards. Tagovailoa completed 15 of 21 passes with two interceptions to give him a league-leading 12 picks this season. It was also the most dominant performance of the season for Miami‚Äôs defense, which had three takeaways and three sacks. Josh Allen threw for 306 yards and two touchdowns, with an interception and fumble, but was replaced by Mitchell Trubisky after Achane‚Äôs second TD put the Dolphins up by 17 with three minutes left.

Continue reading...

item.title: US agriculture department tells states to ‚Äòundo‚Äô Snap benefits for families in need
item.description:
Directive comes after supreme court order allowing Trump officials to pause food aid payments amid shutdown

The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is directing states to ‚Äúimmediately undo‚Äù any steps that have been taken to send out full food aid benefits to low-income Americans, following a supreme court order on Friday that temporarily halted a lower court order requiring those payments.

The USDA‚Äôs directive, issued in a memo on Saturday, followed a supreme court order granting the Trump administration‚Äôs emergency request to pause an order for the USDA to provide full Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits during the ongoing federal government shutdown, which is now in its 40th day.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Directive comes after supreme court order allowing Trump officials to pause food aid payments amid shutdown
The US Department of Agriculture (USDA) is directing states to ‚Äúimmediately undo‚Äù any steps that have been taken to send out full food aid benefits to low-income Americans, following a [supreme court order](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/07/white-house-snap-november-court-order) on Friday that temporarily halted a lower court order requiring those payments.
The USDA‚Äôs directive, issued in a [memo](https://www.fns.usda.gov/snap/updated-supplemental-nutrition-assistance-program-snap-november-benefit-issuance11-8) on Saturday, followed a supreme court order granting the [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration)‚Äôs emergency request to pause an order for the USDA to provide full Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits during the ongoing [federal government shutdown](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-federal-government-shutdown-2025), which is now in its 40th day.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/09/usda-trump-undo-snap-food-aid-payments)

item.title: Hall of Famer and former Raptors coach Lenny Wilkens dies at 88
item.description: Lenny Wilkens, a three-time inductee into the Basketball Hall of Fame who was enshrined as both a player and a coach, has died, his family said Sunday. He was 88. The family said Wilkens was surrounded by loved ones when he died and did not immediately release a cause of death.

item.title: US sports betting crisis grows as MLB‚Äôs Clase and Ortiz indicted over alleged rigged pitches
item.description:
• Pair could face 65 years in prison if found guilty

  • NBA also caught up in its own gambling scandal

The betting crisis in US sports has spread further after Cleveland Guardians players Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz were indicted over an alleged scheme to rig pitches during games.

Bettors on baseball can gamble on whether individual pitches will be balls or strikes. Prosecutors allege claim that Ortiz was paid $5,000 for throwing an intentional ball during a game on 15 June. His teammate Clase, a three-time All-Star, is alleged to have been given $5,000 for facilitating the rigged pitch, alongside gamblers in the players‚Äô home country of the Dominican Republic. Prosecutors claim the pair did so again in a game on 27 June, receiving $7,000 each.

Continue reading...

- Pair could face 65 years in prison if found guilty
- NBA also caught up in its own gambling scandal

item.description:

Paul Tagliabue, who helped usher in a lucrative era for the NFL during his 17 years as commissioner but was criticized for not taking stronger action on concussions has died at the age of 84.

NFL spokesman Brian McCarthy said Tagliabue‚Äôs family informed the league of his death in Chevy Chase, Maryland, on Sunday.

item.title: Ghislaine Maxwell reportedly ‚Äòmuch happier‚Äô after prison transfer by Trump officials
item.description:
Jeffrey Epstein associate, serving 20 years for sex-trafficking crimes, is now in minimum-security federal prison in Texas

Longtime Jeffrey Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell, who is serving a 20-year prison sentence for sex-trafficking crimes, has reportedly said that she is ‚Äúmuch, much happier‚Äù after the Trump administration transferred her to a minimum-security federal prison in Texas, according to emails obtained by NBC News.

Maxwell, 63, was moved from a low-security prison in Tallahassee, Florida, to the minimum-security Federal Prison Camp Bryan in Texas in August ‚Äì just days after she was interviewed about the Epstein case by deputy attorney general, Todd Blanche. Blanche is a former personal lawyer for Donald Trump, who had been friends with the late Epstein ‚Äì a convicted sex offender ‚Äì before winning two presidencies.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Jeffrey Epstein associate, serving 20 years for sex-trafficking crimes, is now in minimum-security federal prison in Texas
Longtime [Jeffrey Epstein](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/jeffrey-epstein) associate [Ghislaine Maxwell](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ghislaine-maxwell), who is serving a 20-year prison sentence for [sex-trafficking crimes](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/dec/29/ghislaine-maxwell-sex-trafficking-trial-verdict), has reportedly said that she is ‚Äúmuch, much happier‚Äù after the Trump administration transferred her to a minimum-security federal prison in Texas, according to emails obtained by [NBC News](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/ghislaine-maxwell-prison-emails-minimum-security-bryan-texas-rcna242218).
Maxwell, 63, was [moved](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/01/ghislaine-maxwell-prison-transfer) from a low-security prison in Tallahassee, Florida, to the minimum-security Federal Prison Camp Bryan in Texas in August ‚Äì¬†just days after she was [interviewed](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/jul/25/ghislaine-maxwell-justice-department-meeting) about the Epstein case by deputy attorney general, Todd Blanche. Blanche is a former personal lawyer for [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump), who had been friends with the late Epstein ‚Äì a convicted sex offender ‚Äì before winning two presidencies.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/09/ghislaine-maxwell-trump-admin-prison-transfer)

item.title: Thousands fill Bell Centre demanding Quebec suspend law reforming doctors' pay
item.description: Thousands of doctors, medical students and supporters filled the Bell Centre on Sunday to demand the Quebec government suspend Bill 2. The law links a part of physicians' pay to performance indicators relating to, for example, the number of patients they care for or the number of surgeries performed.

item.title: They flew to New York to help Mamdani ‚Äì now they want to bring the hope to LA
item.description:
Activists in Los Angeles say the energy from the Hollywood strikes has been reignited by the success of the mayor-elect

While the excitement for mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani has radiated through New York, his win has also energized young activists across the country ‚Äì particularly some in Los Angeles, who flew to the east coast to canvass for Mamdani and now want to bring their experiences westward.

Standing near the poll site at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Neda Davarpanah ‚Äì a screenwriter and actor based in Los Angeles ‚Äì was inspired by Mamdani‚Äôs campaign for mayor so she flew out to New York in late October to canvass on the Upper East Side.

item.title: US flight cancellations rise as Sean Duffy warns travel could reduce to a ‚Äòtrickle‚Äô
item.description:
Over 2,500 flights cancelled as transportation secretary says flight reductions could reach 20% if shutdown persists

Flight cancellations and delays are set to grow as airline passengers across the United States spent the weekend grappling with those issues at major airports nationwide after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) mandated a 4% reduction in air traffic in response to the ongoing federal government shutdown.

If the shutdown continues, the FAA has instructed airlines to cut 6% of flights on Tuesday ‚Äì and to do the same to 10% by 14 November. The transportation secretary, Sean Duffy, has warned that flight reductions could reach 20% if the shutdown persists, and on Sunday he predicted a ‚Äúsubstantial‚Äù number of people in the US would be unable to celebrate the upcoming holidays with their families if the shutdown wasn‚Äôt resolved.

Continue reading...

item.title: What we lose when we surrender care to algorithms | Eric Reinhart
item.description:
A dangerous faith in AI is sweeping American healthcare ‚Äì with consequences for the basis of society itself

The computer interrupted while Pamela was still speaking. I had accompanied her ‚Äì my dear friend ‚Äì to a recent doctor‚Äôs appointment. She is in her 70s, lives alone while navigating multiple chronic health issues, and has been getting short of breath climbing the front stairs to her apartment. In the exam room, she spoke slowly and self-consciously, the way people often do when they are trying to describe their bodies and anxieties to strangers. Midway through her description of how she had been feeling, the doctor clicked his mouse and a block of text began to bloom across the computer monitor.

The clinic had adopted an artificial-intelligence scribe, and it was transcribing and summarizing the conversation in real time. It was also highlighting keywords, suggesting diagnostic possibilities and providing billing codes. The doctor, apparently satisfied that his computer had captured an adequate description of Pamela‚Äôs chief complaint and symptoms, turned away from us and began reviewing the text on the screen as Pamela kept speaking.

Continue reading...

item.title: California‚Äôs drying Salton Sea harms the lungs of people living nearby, say researchers
item.description:
Experts suspect that dust from the sea contains endotoxic bacteria membranes caused by fertilizer runoff

Chemical-laden dust from southern California‚Äôs drying Salton Sea is likely harming the lungs of people around the shrinking body of water, and the effects are especially pronounced in children, new peer-reviewed research from the University of California, Irvine, shows.

A separate peer-reviewed study from the University of California, Riverside, also found the Salton Sea‚Äôs contaminated dust seemed to alter lung microbiome, which could trigger pulmonary issues that have been reported around the lake.

Continue reading...

Experts suspect that dust from the sea contains endotoxic bacteria membranes caused by fertilizer runoff
Chemical-laden dust from southern [California](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/california)‚Äôs drying Salton Sea is likely harming the lungs of people around the shrinking body of water, and the effects are especially pronounced in children, new [peer-reviewed research](https://www.atsjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1164/rccm.202504-0799RL) from the University of California, Irvine, shows.
A separate [peer-reviewed study](https://journals.asm.org/doi/10.1128/msphere.00209-25) from the University of California, Riverside, also found the Salton Sea‚Äôs contaminated dust seemed to alter lung microbiome, which could trigger pulmonary issues that have been reported around the lake.

item.title: ‚ÄòToo far? I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôve gone far enough!‚Äô The founder of Peta on gruesome stunts and her bloody fight for animal rights
item.description:
After 45 years as chief fake blood thrower, Ingrid Newkirk is still waging war on everything from leather to cashmere. Is she still relevant?

Ingrid Newkirk was 54 when she thought she was going to die in a plane crash. It was late summer and the founder of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) was flying from Minneapolis in the US to the company HQ in Norfolk, Virginia when her plane encountered strong wind shear. The pilot attempted an emergency landing, but failed; back up they went.

On the third attempt, with ‚Äúa teaspoon of fuel‚Äù in the tank, he finally got the plane down safely. During those moments, Newkirk, now 76, scribbled a will on a napkin. She has tweaked it over the years, but it still reads like a horror movie prop list: her liver is to be sent to France to be made into foie gras, her skin to Herm√®s to create a handbag and her lips to whichever US president is in power, to shame them for granting a ‚Äúpatronising‚Äù pardon to a turkey each Thanksgiving. As wills go, it‚Äôs straight out of the Peta playbook: an audacious stunt of the kind that has made them the world‚Äôs most well-known, successful and in some quarters reviled animal rights organisation. ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôll never be made a dame,‚Äù Newkirk says, laughing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm too controversial.‚Äù

Continue reading...

As wills go, it‚Äôs straight out of the [Peta](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/peta) playbook: an audacious stunt of the kind that has made them the world‚Äôs most well-known, successful and in some quarters reviled animal rights organisation. ‚ÄúI know I‚Äôll never be made a dame,‚Äù Newkirk says, laughing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm too controversial.‚Äù

item.title: Trump‚Äôs assault on voting intensifies as midterms loom:‚Äòa wholesale attack on free and fair elections‚Äô
item.description:
White House is manipulating voting system, from redistricting to rule changes, to affect midterms

A year out from the 2026 midterms, with Republicans feeling the blows from a string of losses in this week‚Äôs elections, Donald Trump and his allies are mounting a multipronged attack on almost every aspect of voting in the United States and raising what experts say are troubling questions about the future of one of the world‚Äôs oldest democracies.

While Democratic leaders continue to invest their hopes in a ‚Äúblue wave‚Äù to overturn Republican majorities in the House and Senate next year, Trump and some prominent supporters have sought to discredit the possibility that Republicans could lose in a fair fight and are using that premise to justify demands for a drastically different kind of electoral system.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
White House is manipulating voting system, from redistricting to rule changes, to affect midterms
A year out from the 2026 midterms, with [Republicans](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/republicans) feeling the blows from a string of losses in this week‚Äôs elections, [Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) and his allies are mounting a multipronged attack on almost every aspect of voting in the United States and raising what experts say are troubling questions about the future of one of the world‚Äôs oldest democracies.
While Democratic leaders continue to invest their hopes in a ‚Äú [blue wave](https://www.politico.com/news/2025/08/03/democrats-blue-wave-2026-midterms-00489291)‚Äù to overturn Republican majorities in the [House](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/house-of-representatives) and [Senate](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-senate) next year, Trump and some prominent supporters have sought to discredit the possibility that Republicans could lose in a fair fight and are using that premise to justify demands for a drastically different kind of electoral system.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/09/trump-midterm-elections-voting-system)

item.title: Trump tariffs and strict US border rules threaten flight of Canada‚Äôs ‚Äòsnowbirds‚Äô
item.description:
Annual migration from frigid Canadian winter to Florida sunshine could become thinner as travellers look elsewhere

The annual migration of hundreds of thousands of Canadian ‚Äúsnowbirds‚Äù escaping freezing temperatures in their homeland and heading to warmer US states such as Florida for the duration of the winter could be about to become noticeably thinner.

Many have ditched plans to visit their southern neighbor and are looking to spend their valuable dollars elsewhere, largely put off by Donald Trump‚Äôs escalating economic war with Canada and strict new immigration rules that have created fear and confusion.

Continue reading...

item.title: Rescued California hunter thought he‚Äôd have to watch family ‚Äòfrom heaven‚Äô ‚Äì and offers advice
item.description:
Ron Dailey, 65, survived nearly three weeks in the frosty, mountainous wilderness after taking a wrong turn

The California hunter who spent nearly three weeks stranded in the frosty, mountainous wilderness reportedly survived by rationing out the little food he brought with him ‚Äì eating 70 or fewer calories daily for a stretch ‚Äì as well as consuming melted snow to stay hydrated.

Yet before his 1 November rescue, 65-year-old Ron Dailey was so unsure whether anyone would save him that he tried to text his family regrets for possibly missing the rest of their lives ‚Äì while assuring them that he would watch them ‚Äúfrom heaven‚Äù.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump‚Äôs dollar delusion: how trade war risks ending the US‚Äôs ‚Äòexorbitant privilege‚Äô
item.description:
Trump‚Äôs team flirts with weakening the dollar, threatening US influence, low borrowing costs and global stability

Magical thinking is indispensable to understanding Team Trump‚Äôs economic policymaking. The White House often seems to believe two opposing policies can work together while one policy can do two or three contradictory things.

A heavy dose of hocus pocus will be needed to make the administration‚Äôs dollar policy work in the interest of the United States, for it appears that they want to end the US dollar‚Äôs supremacy in global finance.

item.title: How Mamdani is defying immigrant expectations by embracing his identity: ‚ÄòHis boldness resonates‚Äô
item.description:
New York City mayor-elect refused to ‚Äòbe in the shadows‚Äô in the face of Islamophobic attacks during his campaign

Across the country, Donald Trump‚Äôs crackdown on immigrants has shaken neighbourhoods, torn apart families and engendered a sense of panic among communities. But in New York, on Tuesday night, Zohran Mamdani, the first Muslim mayor of New York, and an immigrant from Uganda, chose to underline his identity. ‚ÄúNew York will remain a city of immigrants: a city built by immigrants, powered by immigrants and, as of tonight, led by an immigrant,‚Äù he told an ecstatic crowd at Paramount theater in Brooklyn.

The son of a Muslim father and a Hindu mother, he was born in Kampala, raised in New York, and identifies as a democratic socialist. Almost every aspect of Mamdani‚Äôs identity had been an issue of contention during the election. Earlier this week, the Center for Study of Organized Hate published a report highlighting the surge in Islamophobic comments online between July and October, most of which labelled Mamdani as an extremist or terrorist.

Continue reading...

item.title: Many would-be buyers are frozen out of the housing market
item.description: Only about one in five homes sold in the last year went to a first-time buyer. And the average person buying their first home was 40 years old ‚Äî a record high. A new report from the National Association of Realtors shows how challenging it's become for young people to get a foothold in today's costly housing market.

item.title: America‚Äôs men‚Äôs grand slam drought is not Taylor Fritz‚Äôs burden to carry
item.description:
Back at the ATP finals one year after reaching the last hurdle, Fritz remains a top-five talent. It‚Äôs a reminder that a certain major-title drought is not his burden to bear

I would like to have some words with ESPN broadcaster Chris Fowler about what he said after Novak Djokovic beat Taylor Fritz, for the 11th straight time, in the US Open quarter-finals. Look ‚Äì Fritz is American, Fowler is American ‚Äì and sports often lend themselves to nationalism. A little bit of disappointment was appropriate. Instead, Fowler invoked the continued drought of American men at the majors: none of them had lifted a trophy since Andy Roddick in 2003, and Fritz had been the last one standing in the tournament.

We all love a narrative, myself included. But come on. Even if Fritz had beaten Djokovic for the first time, force of nature Carlos Alcaraz was waiting in the next round, who Fritz has yet to beat in an official match. And if he‚Äôd somehow survived that, it would have been defending champion Jannik Sinner in the final, against whom Fritz had lost 10 of the last 11 sets. Alcaraz and Sinner had also split the last seven major titles (and Alcaraz went on to thrash a fatigued Djokovic in the next round). Fritz said in press after the loss that he actually liked his draw, because it presented the opportunity to beat the three best players in the world in succession. Fritz is more than within his right to aspire to the accomplishment; an athlete is meant to believe in themselves. But going into that Djokovic quarter-final who else in their right mind had the drought of American champions on the brain?

Continue reading...

We all love a narrative, myself included. But come _on._ Even if Fritz had beaten Djokovic for the first time, force of nature Carlos Alcaraz was waiting in the next round, who Fritz has yet to beat in an official match. Alcaraz and Sinner had also split the last seven major titles (and Alcaraz went on to thrash a fatigued Djokovic in the next round). item.description:

US airlines canceled 1,460 flights on Saturday, the second day of the Federal Aviation Administration‚Äôs (FAA) order to reduce air traffic because of the government shutdown.

So far, the slowdown at many of the nation‚Äôs busiest airports hasn‚Äôt caused widespread disruptions. But it has deepened the impact felt by what is now the nation‚Äôs longest federal shutdown.

item.title: Senate Republicans embrace Trump‚Äôs call ‚Äì from his Florida golf course ‚Äì to replace Obamacare
item.description:
Amid a historic government shutdown, some senators on Capitol Hill are working this weekend on an unpopular bill

US senators are working through the weekend for the first time since the government shutdown began more than a month ago, but hopes for a bipartisan agreement on how to end the standoff, and keep healthcare affordable for millions of Americans, appeared to recede as Republican senators floated a proposal toxic to Democrats: scrapping the Affordable Care Act (ACA), known as Obamacare.

The impact on Americans from the longest shutdown of the federal government in history deepened on Saturday, as federal workers went unpaid, airlines were forced to cancel flights and Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (Snap) benefits have been delayed for 42 million Americans.

Continue reading...

item.title: Car fleeing police slams into bar in Tampa, killing 4 people and injuring 11
item.description:
Police say vehicle was involved in street racing before driver fled from authorities and then crashed into Ybor City bar

A speeding car fleeing police slammed into a crowded bar early on Saturday, killing four people and injuring 11 in a historic district of Tampa, Florida, known for its nightlife and tourists.

An air patrol unit with the Tampa police department spotted the car driving recklessly on a freeway at about 12.40am after police said the silver sedan had been seen street racing in another neighborhood, according to a police department statement.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump reportedly wants new NFL stadium in Washington named after him
item.description:
• Trump wants name on Commanders home, per ESPN

  • White House source says move ‚Äòwill probably happen‚Äô

  • $3.7bn, 65,000-seat stadium expected to open in 2030

Donald Trump is pressing the NFL‚Äôs Washington Commanders to name their planned $3.7bn stadium after him, a bid he is pursuing through back-channel conversations with ownership and by leaning on the government bodies that must approve the project, according to multiple sources familiar with the discussions.

A senior White House official said Trump has conveyed his wishes directly to a member of investor Josh Harris‚Äôs ownership group. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what the president wants, and it will probably happen,‚Äù the official told ESPN. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt added in an email: ‚ÄúThat would be a beautiful name, as it was President Trump who made the rebuilding of the new stadium possible.‚Äù

Continue reading...

- $3.7bn, 65,000-seat stadium expected to open in 2030
Donald Trump is pressing the NFL‚Äôs Washington Commanders to name their planned $3.7bn stadium after him, a bid he is pursuing through back-channel conversations with ownership and by leaning on the government bodies that must approve the project, according to multiple sources familiar with the discussions.
A senior White House official said Trump has conveyed his wishes directly to a member of investor Josh Harris‚Äôs ownership group. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs what the president wants, and it will probably happen,‚Äù the official [told ESPN](https://www.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/46892115/trump-wants-commanders-stadium-named-him). White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt added in an email: ‚ÄúThat would be a beautiful name, as it was President Trump who made the rebuilding of the new stadium possible.‚Äù
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/nov/08/trump-name-washington-commanders-stadium)

item.title: Kristi Noem reportedly tried to buy 10 engineless Spirit Airlines planes that airline didn‚Äôt own
item.description:
DHS secretary arranged purchase to expand deportation flights and for personal travel, Wall Street Journal reports

The secretary of the US Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Kristi Noem, reportedly authorized the purchase of Spirit Airlines jets before discovering the airline didn‚Äôt actually own the planes ‚Äì and that the aircraft lacked engines.

The bizarre anecdote was contained in a Wall Street Journal report released on Friday, which recounted how Noem and Corey Lewandowski ‚Äì who managed Donald Trump‚Äôs first winning presidential campaign ‚Äì had recently arranged to buy 10 Boeing 737 aircraft from Spirit Airlines. People familiar with the situation told the paper that the two intended to use the jets to expand deportation flights ‚Äì and for personal travel.

Continue reading...

item.title: Driver livestreams herself on TikTok as she apparently hits and kills man in Chicago
item.description:
TikTok video shows woman speaking into camera and reacting to a loud thud before she says ‚ÄòI just hit somebody‚Äô

Authorities are investigating a newly surfaced video that suggests a woman who hit and killed a man while driving in the Chicago suburb of Zion, Illinois, on Monday night was livestreaming on TikTok at the time of the crash.

The video in question was reportedly taken by a user in Zion, and it shows a woman behind the wheel of a car reacting to a loud thud by saying, ‚ÄúFuck, fuck, fuck ‚Ä¶ I just hit somebody.‚Äù

item.title: Palestinian American hails Virginia win: ‚ÄòYou can be bold on the Gaza genocide and still be victorious‚Äô
item.description:
Democrat Sam Rasoul, a Muslim, won re-election to the state legislature despite accusations of antisemitism

Sam Rasoul, the Virginia Democrat who is currently the longest-serving Muslim state lawmaker in the US and who faced accusations of antisemitism over language condemning Israel‚Äôs assault on Gaza as genocide, scored a resounding victory in Tuesday‚Äôs election that he believes shows voters are craving honesty from politicians.

Rasoul, an American Palestinian state legislator since 2014, strengthened his majority as he was re-elected to an area of Virginia where the city of Roanoke leans Democrat and the surrounding areas are deeply conservative. In an election seen as a referendum on Trump‚Äôs policies, which have disproportionately affected Virginia, Rasoul increased his vote share from four years ago by more than 5% as Democrats trounced Republicans from the legislature to the governor‚Äôs mansion.

Continue reading...

item.title: Near Ohio air force base, food pantries and businesses grapple with effects of shutdown
item.description:
As tens of thousands of military personnel work without pay and others are furloughed, a local pantry sees its numbers increasing as restaurants are losing customers

When Jane Doorley and her husband Bill arrived at the Fairborn Fish Food Pantry they help run on 28 October, they couldn‚Äôt get into the parking lot, such was the number of cars belonging to people seeking food.

‚ÄúOur numbers are way up. Last Friday was really bad too,‚Äù says Jane. ‚ÄúAround 250 families, including 300 children, come to the pantry every day it‚Äôs open.‚Äù

item.title: Democrats just won back Latinos who voted for Trump. Will they be convinced to stick around?
item.description:
Though Latino voters gave sweeping support to Democrats in Tuesday‚Äôs elections, they‚Äôre not a permanent coalition

Latino voters delivered sweeping support to Democratic candidates across multiple states in Tuesday‚Äôs off-year elections, reversing what many Republicans had come to believe was a lasting political realignment after Donald Trump‚Äôs historic gains with the community in the 2024 election .

The rapid reversal represents one of the most volatile electoral swings in recent memory and threatens to upend Republican redistricting strategies that banked on sustained support from Latinos, the fastest-growing voting bloc in the country. It also suggests that Trump‚Äôs appeal to Latino voters was highly personal rather than an embrace of the Republican party itself ‚Äì a miscalculation that could reshape the landscape heading into the 2026 midterms.

Continue reading...

item.title: Washington National Opera may move out of Kennedy Center due to Trump ‚Äòtakeover‚Äô
item.description:
Ticket sales at about 40% unsold compared with before president made himself chair of US performing arts center

The Washington National Opera (WNO) is considering moving out of the Kennedy Center, the company‚Äôs home since the US‚Äôs national performing arts center opened in 1971.

The possibility has been forced on the company as a result of the ‚Äútakeover‚Äù of the center by Donald Trump, according to WNO‚Äôs artistic director, Francesca Zambello. The president declared himself chair of the institution in February, sacking and replacing its board and leadership.

Continue reading...

item.title: Businesses worldwide brace for extra Trump tariffs on steel imports
item.description:
Commerce department expected to add about 700 more items with steel content to levy list at request of US firms

Businesses around the world are steeling themselves for another round of Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs, this time on goods ranging from bicycles to baking trays, as US industry embraces a call for more products to tax on import.

Small, medium and large American companies have asked the US Department of Commerce to add about 700 more items to an August list of 407 products already facing extra tariffs because of their steel content, which hit items such as Ikea tables with metal nuts and bolts and German combine harvesters.

Continue reading...

item.title: Zohran Mamdani has upended US politics. Now he should take on Fifa | Jules Boykoff
item.description:
New York‚Äôs mayor-elect has taken on powerful institutions. With the World Cup taking place in his city, he should challenge Fifa next

After winning the election for mayor of New York City, an exuberant Zohran Mamdani took to the stage at his victory speech and said, ‚ÄúIf there is any way to terrify a despot, it is by dismantling the very conditions that allowed him to accumulate power.‚Äù He was alluding to Donald Trump, but the sentiment also applies to Fifa, the world‚Äôs governing body for soccer.

In September, Mamdani‚Äôs team kicked off a ‚ÄúGame Over Greed‚Äù campaign targeting Fifa‚Äôs use of dynamic pricing for 2026 men‚Äôs World Cup tickets, calling it an ‚Äúaffront to the game.‚Äù His petition demanded that Fifa cease its rapacious dynamic pricing scheme, place a price cap on tickets that are resold on Fifa‚Äôs ticketing platform, and reserve a tranche of tickets for local residents. Mamdani, a longtime Arsenal fan, told the Guardian‚Äôs Football Weekly podcast, ‚ÄúI have long been quite troubled by how the supposed stewards of the game have opted for profit time and time again at the expense of the people that love this game.‚Äù

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
New York‚Äôs mayor-elect has taken on powerful institutions. With the World Cup taking place in his city, he should challenge Fifa next
After [winning the election](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/04/zohran-mamdani-mayor-new-york-city) for mayor of New York City, an exuberant Zohran Mamdani took to the stage at his victory speech and [said](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/05/zohran-mamdani-victory-speech-transcript), ‚ÄúIf there is any way to terrify a despot, it is by dismantling the very conditions that allowed him to accumulate power.‚Äù He was alluding to Donald Trump, but the sentiment also applies to Fifa, the world‚Äôs governing body for soccer.
In September, Mamdani‚Äôs team kicked off a ‚ÄúGame Over Greed‚Äù [campaign](https://www.zohranfornyc.com/gameovergreed) targeting Fifa‚Äôs use of dynamic pricing for 2026 men‚Äôs World Cup tickets, [calling](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2025/sep/10/zohran-mamdani-interview-fifa-petition-dynamic-pricing-football-weekly) it an ‚Äúaffront to the game.‚Äù His petition demanded that Fifa cease its rapacious dynamic pricing scheme, place a price cap on tickets that are resold on Fifa‚Äôs ticketing platform, and reserve a tranche of tickets for local residents. Mamdani, a longtime Arsenal fan, told the [Guardian‚Äôs Football Weekly](https://www.theguardian.com/football/audio/2025/sep/11/manchester-united-city-derby-moldova-misery-zoran-mamdani-football-weekly-podcast) podcast, ‚ÄúI have long been quite troubled by how the supposed stewards of the game have opted for profit time and time again at the expense of the people that love this game.‚Äù
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/football/2025/nov/08/zohran-mamdani-has-upended-us-politics-now-he-should-take-on-fifa)

item.title: Maha movement helps to kill bill seeking US food-safety rollbacks
item.description:
Public health advocates praise rewrite of legislation backed by big-food influence operation AFIT

A bipartisan group of public health advocates have defeated a proposal to kill state food safety laws that was pushed by what some critics have called a ‚Äúfaux Maha‚Äù big-food influence operation.

The industry-funded group, called Americans for Ingredient Transparency (AFIT), suggests it is part of a grassroots Make America Healthy Again (Maha) movement, but opponents say it is waging a campaign on behalf of big food companies that Maha figures typically criticize ‚Äì ConAgra, Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, Hormel and Nestl√©, among other food giants.

Continue reading...

item.title: A year after devastating Trump loss, have the Democrats begun to find their way back?
item.description:
Party was shell-shocked after 2024 defeat but Tuesday night‚Äôs coast-to-coast romp signals brighter times ahead

It has been a year of soul-searching, hand-wringing, and self-flagellation for Democrats after a ballot-box rejection so thorough that some had come to believe that the party had lost not only the White House and Congress but the culture itself.

Shell-shocked, Democrats entered Donald Trump‚Äôs second term in a political stupor ‚Äì unsure of who they were or what they stood for. Their base had lost faith in its aging leadership class, and their brand, in Democrats‚Äô own words, had become ‚Äútoxic‚Äù: a party increasingly confined to coastal states, big cities and college towns. And even there, warning signs were flashing.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Party was shell-shocked after 2024 defeat but Tuesday night‚Äôs coast-to-coast romp signals brighter times ahead
It has been a year of soul-searching, hand-wringing, and self-flagellation for [Democrats](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/democrats) after a ballot-box rejection so thorough that some had come to believe that the party had lost not only the White House and Congress but [the culture itself](https://www.npr.org/2024/11/14/nx-s1-5183075/did-democrats-lose-on-the-economy-or-the-culture-wars-three-strategists-weigh-in).
Shell-shocked, Democrats entered Donald Trump‚Äôs second term in a political stupor ‚Äì unsure of who they were or what they stood for. Their base had lost faith in its aging leadership class, and their brand, in Democrats‚Äô own words, had become ‚Äú [toxic](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/29/us/politics/newsom-democrats-toxic.html)‚Äù: a party increasingly confined to coastal states, big cities and college towns. And [even there](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/11/06/us/politics/presidential-election-2024-red-shift.html), warning signs were flashing.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/08/democrats-trump-elections)

item.title: Joy Reid on her ouster from MSNBC: ‚ÄòIn this moment, not being a part of corporate media is a gift‚Äô
item.description:
After the ex-host of the ReidOut was forced out in February, she launched her own streaming show on YouTube

Joy Reid hosted the 7pm hour on MSNBC for nearly five years, providing a daily dose of progressive energy and verve that led into the network‚Äôs primetime programming. Then, in late February, Reid was suddenly forced out, and her show, The ReidOut, was cancelled as part of a broader programming shakeup at the network. Reid has since launched her own streaming show, The Joy Reid Show, and has a few things to say about the mainstream media she was once part of.

Now that it‚Äôs been eight months since you were abruptly fired by MSNBC, how do you view your departure?

Continue reading...

item.title: ShutdownTok: federal workers detail life without pay amid government‚Äôs closure
item.description:
Federal employees on social media share practical tips and document lives amid longest US shutdown in history

As the US government shutdown stretches on after becoming the longest in history, influencers and content creators have stepped into improvised public-service roles by chronicling life without paychecks.

Across TikTok, Instagram and YouTube, federal workers have been publishing ‚Äúshutdown vlogs‚Äù that mix dark humor with practical tips. The federal shutdown has created its own internet sub-genre of resource directories, budget-stretching advice threads and mental health check-ins.

item.title: The LA Dodgers won the World Series but for Latino fans, it‚Äôs complicated
item.description:
The fact that Latino stars were at the forefront of the victory over the Toronto Blue Jays sits alongside the club‚Äôs near silence on the immigration raids roiling the city

For Natalia Molina, a lifelong fan of the Los Angeles Dodgers and a third-generation Mexican American, the crowning moment of baseball‚Äôs World Series didn‚Äôt come in last Saturday‚Äôs nail-biting finale, when her team performed one death-defying escape act after another before prevailing in extra innings over the Toronto Blue Jays.

It came a game earlier, when two of the team‚Äôs second-tier players, Kike Hern√°ndez, who is from Puerto Rico, and Miguel Rojas, from Venezuela, pulled off a thrilling, game-winning sequence that simultaneously upended the many negative stereotypes Donald Trump has been touting about Latinos since he first ran for president a decade ago.

Continue reading...

item.title: World‚Äôs longest-married couple reveals key to a lasting relationship: ‚ÄòWe love each other‚Äô
item.description:
Eleanor Gittens, 107, and Lyle Gittens, 108, of Miami met at a basketball game in 1941 and have been married for 83 years

A Miami husband and wife who recently attained the title of world‚Äôs longest-married couple say they managed that feat just by loving one another.

‚ÄúWe love each other,‚Äù Eleanor Gittens, 107, said to LongeviQuest when the website specializing on people who are in their second century of life asked what was the secret to her 83 years of marriage to her husband, Lyle.

item.title: UPS grounds all its MD-11 planes after deadly Louisville crash

The freight company UPS has grounded its fleet of MD-11 aircraft days after a cargo plane crash that killed at least 13 people in Kentucky.

The grounded MD-11s are the same type of plane involved in Tuesday‚Äôs crash in Louisville. They were originally built by McDonnell Douglas until it was taken over by Boeing.

item.title: Trump-Orb√°n meeting: US gives Hungary exemption from sanctions on Russian oil and gas
item.description:
US president also praises Hungarian leader‚Äôs hardline stance on immigration during friendly White House summit

The US has granted Hungary a one-year exemption from US sanctions on importing oil and gas from Russia, according to a White House official, after Viktor Orb√°n pressed his case for a reprieve during a meeting with Donald Trump in Washington.

Last month, Trump imposed Ukraine-related sanctions on Russian oil companies Lukoil and Rosneft that carried the threat of further sanctions on entities in countries buying oil from them.

item.title: ‚ÄòHuge victory‚Äô in Portland as judge‚Äôs final order bars Trump from sending national guard
item.description:
Karin Immergut said earlier she ‚Äòfound no credible evidence‚Äô that protests in Oregon city were out of control

A federal judge in Oregon on Friday blocked Donald Trump from deploying national guard troops to Portland, ruling there was no evidence of widespread violence to justify federal intervention.

The US district court judge, Karin Immergut, a Trump appointee, delivered her final order in the case on Friday. She found that protests near Portland‚Äôs Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) facility were ‚Äúpredominately peaceful, with only isolated and sporadic instances of relatively low-level violence‚Äù.

item.title: US grants Hungary one-year exception from sanctions over Russian oil and gas
item.description:
Viktor Orb√°n had a friendly meeting with Donald Trump on Friday to press his case for a reprieve

The United States has granted Hungary a one-year exemption from US sanctions for using Russian oil and gas, a White House official said on Friday, after Viktor Orb√°n pressed his case for a reprieve during a friendly meeting with Donald Trump in Washington.

Last month, Trump imposed Ukraine-related sanctions on Russian oil companies Lukoil and Rosneft that carried the threat of further sanctions on entities in countries that buy oil from those firms.

Last month, Trump imposed [Ukraine-related sanctions](https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/us-announces-sanctions-russian-oil-companies-rosneft-lukoil-2025-10-22/) on Russian oil companies Lukoil and Rosneft that carried the threat of further sanctions on entities in countries that buy oil from those firms.

item.title: Republicans reject Democrats‚Äô proposal to end longest shutdown in US history
item.description:
Chuck Schumer offered a deal to reopen the government in exchange for a one-year healthcare subsidies extension

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

Republicans rejected a proposal made on Friday by the Senate‚Äôs Democratic leader, Chuck Schumer, which would end the longest government shutdown in US history by offering Republicans a deal to reauthorize funding in exchange for a one-year extension of tax credits that lower costs for Affordable Care Act (ACA) health plans.

‚ÄúDemocrats are ready to clear the way to quickly pass a government funding bill that includes healthcare affordability,‚Äù Schumer said on the Senate floor. ‚ÄúLeader Thune just needs to add a clean, one-year extension of the ACA tax credits to the CR so that we can immediately address rising healthcare costs.‚Äù

Continue reading...

item.title: ICE facing fierce backlash after video apparently shows unconscious man clutching child during arrest
item.description:
Footage shows commotion inside vehicle in Massachusetts as desperate woman in passenger seat tries to awaken man

US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is facing fierce questions after a video that appeared to show a man falling unconscious during an arrest while clutching a small child went viral, and officials accused the man of faking a medical emergency to stop the arrest of his wife.

The footage, obtained by the Boston Globe, shows a frantic commotion inside a vehicle in Fitchburg, Massachusetts, on Thursday. A desperate woman in the passenger seat tries to awaken the man in the driver‚Äôs seat, with a crying child in the middle. People can be heard shouting: ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs having a seizure.‚Äù An officer can be seen trying to pull the passengers from the vehicle, while a Fitchburg police officer orders the crowd to ‚Äúback up‚Äù repeatedly.

Continue reading...

item.title: Consumer sentiment hits three-year low
item.description:
Consumer sentiment ‚Äî as in, how everyday people feel about the economy ‚Äî fell to a low not seen since 2022, according to the University of Michigan‚Äôs Surveys of Consumers. The decline was consistent across demographics, except among the wealthiest Americans (as measured by volume of stock market holdings). In other words, economic mood just became another k-shaped indicator. Also in this episode: Colleges shutter satellite campuses to cut costs and small and midsize businesses shrink their headcounts.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.


Marketplace is more than a radio show. Check out our original reporting and financial literacy content at¬†marketplace.org¬†‚Äî and consider¬†making an investment¬†in our future.

item.title: Indiana woman who was at wrong home address to clean fatally shot by resident
item.description:
Officers found Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez dead after she accidentally went to a wrong property

Authorities in Indiana are considering whether to charge a homeowner who they say shot and killed a woman after she mistakenly went to the wrong address where she thought she was turning up to clean a property.

Police officers found Maria Florinda Rios Perez De Velasquez, 32, dead just before 7am Wednesday on the front porch of a home in Whitestown, an Indianapolis suburb of about 10,000 people.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump says US will boycott G20 summit in South Africa, citing treatment of white farmers
item.description:
Administration has long accused South Africa of allowing white Afrikaner farmers to be persecuted and attacked

Donald Trump said Friday that no US government officials would be attending the Group of 20 summit this year in South Africa, citing the country‚Äôs treatment of white farmers.

The US president had already announced he would not attend the annual summit for heads of state from the globe‚Äôs leading and emerging economies. JD Vance had been scheduled to attend in Trump‚Äôs place, but a person familiar with Vance‚Äôs plans who was granted anonymity to talk about his schedule said Vance would no longer travel there for the summit.

Continue reading...

VPM News reporter Patrick Larsen joins Kimberly to debrief the election results and explain why rising energy costs were a key campaign issue‚Äîand what data centers have to do with it. Plus, we‚Äôll play a round of Half Full/Half Empty!

item.title: Passengers start to feel bite of flight cuts amid US government shutdown
item.description:
Travellers forced to adjust their plans as longest shutdown on record continues with no sign of resolution

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

  • List of US airports cutting flights on Friday

A US government order to make drastic cuts in commercial air traffic amid the government shutdown has taken effect, with major airports across the country experiencing a significant reduction in schedules and leaving travellers scrambling to adjust their plans.

The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has said the move is necessary to maintain air traffic control safety during a federal government shutdown, now the longest recorded and with no sign of a resolution, in which air traffic controllers have gone without pay.

Continue reading...

- [List of US airports cutting flights on Friday](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/nov/06/list-airports-flight-cuts-faa)

item.title: James D Watson, who co-discovered DNA‚Äôs twisted-ladder structure, dies aged 97
item.description:
Nobel prize winner shaped medicine, crimefighting and genealogy, but later years marred by racist remarks

James Dewey Watson, whose co-discovery of the twisted-ladder structure of DNA in 1953 helped light the long fuse on a revolution in medicine, crimefighting, genealogy and ethics, has died, according to his former research lab. He was 97.

The breakthrough ‚Äì made when the brash, Chicago-born Watson was just 24 ‚Äì turned him into a hallowed figure in the world of science for decades. But near the end of his life, he faced condemnation and professional censure for offensive remarks, including saying Black people were less intelligent than white people.

Continue reading...

item.title: WTA Finals tennis: Sabalenka beats Anisimova to set up final with Rybakina ‚Äì as it happened
item.description:
Aryna Sabalenka came through a gripping three-set battle with Amanda Anisimova and will face Elena Rybakina, who fought back to defeat Jessica Pegula in the first semi-final

First set: Pegula 2-2* Rybakina (*denotes next server) Rybakina had started the stronger but lost her way in that last service game. Can Pegula back up the break? An early double fault doesn‚Äôt help matters, and Rybakina outlasts her in a rally to earn break point. From the middle of the court, Rybakina lands an inside-out forehand on the line, and we‚Äôre back on serve.

Cam Norrie is playing in the Metz semi-finals; he‚Äôs trailing Lorenzo Sonego 6-4, 0-1. In Athens, Novak Djokovic is facing Yannick Hanfmann; it‚Äôs on serve in their semi-final.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump pardons ex-Mets star Darryl Strawberry over past tax and drug conviction
item.description:
• Trump grants full pardon to New York Mets great

  • Strawberry hit 335 HRs and was eight-time All-Star

  • US president cites faith, sobriety, ministry work

Donald Trump has pardoned former New York Mets great Darryl Strawberry on past tax evasion and drug charges, citing the 1983 National League Rookie of the Year‚Äôs post-career embrace of his Christian faith and longtime sobriety.

Strawberry was an outfielder and eight-time All-Star, including seven with the Mets from 1983 through 1990. He hit 335 homers and had 1,000 RBIs and 221 stolen bases in 17 seasons.

item.title: Students and faculty at over 100 US universities protest against Trump‚Äôs attacks
item.description:
Student, national and local groups across US organized day of action to condemn Trump‚Äôs assault on academic freedom

Students, faculty and staff at more than 100 campuses across the US rallied against the Trump administration‚Äôs assault on higher education on Friday ‚Äì the first in a planned series of nationwide, coordinated protests that organizers hope will culminate in large-scale students‚Äô and workers‚Äô strikes next May Day and a nationwide general strike in May 2028.

The day of action was organized under the banner of Students Rise Up, a network of students including both local groups and national organizations such as Sunrise Movement and Campus Climate Network. Students were joined by faculty and educational workers‚Äô unions like the American Association of University Professors and Higher Education Labor United.

Continue reading...

item.title: Virginia Republican who shared violent texts from prominent Democrat loses re-election
item.description:
Carrie Coyner conceded defeat after igniting text scandal over Democrat imagining ‚Äòtwo bullets‚Äô in rival‚Äôs head

The Virginia Republican politician who shook up multiple statewide elections by disclosing text messages in which a prominent Democratic candidate fantasized about a rival receiving ‚Äútwo bullets to the head‚Äù has conceded defeat in her own bid to retain office.

Carrie Coyner was seeking a third two-year term in Virginia‚Äôs house of delegates when she publicly shared the text messages that she had previously received from Jay Jones, a former Democratic colleague who ran in the state‚Äôs attorney general election on Tuesday.

Continue reading...

item.title: Cornell University settles with Trump administration to restore $250m in funds
item.description:
Upstate New York institution is the fifth university under government investigation to bow to White House demands

Cornell University announced a settlement with the Trump administration on Friday, becoming the fifth university under investigation by the US government to do so.

The agreement will see more than $250m in federal research funding restored. In exchange, the university will share admissions data with the government, pay $30m and invest $30m more in research programs benefiting farmers ‚Äì a reflection of the university‚Äôs longstanding record of agricultural research. Cornell also agreed to continue to ‚Äúevaluate the campus climate‚Äù, particularly for Jewish students, and use the Trump administration‚Äôs interpretation of civil rights laws, which views diversity initiatives as unlawful race-based discrimination, in training materials.

Continue reading...

Upstate New York institution is the fifth university under government investigation to bow to White House demands

In exchange, the university will share admissions data with the government, pay $30m and invest $30m more in research programs benefiting farmers ‚Äì a reflection of the university‚Äôs longstanding record of agricultural research. Cornell also agreed to continue to ‚Äúevaluate the campus climate‚Äù, particularly for Jewish students, and use the Trump administration‚Äôs interpretation of civil rights laws, which views diversity initiatives as unlawful race-based discrimination, in training materials.
