item.title: Some of the earliest written notes in western musical history discovered in Pennsylvania
item.description:
Ninth-century manuscript for Easter services remained ‚Äòout of sight‚Äô for years in hands of private collector

Researchers in Pennsylvania have uncovered what they believe are some of the earliest written notes in western musical history ‚Äì on a ninth-century manuscript they say remained ‚Äúhidden in plain sight‚Äù for years in the hands of a private collector.

The notations ‚Äì characters and dots similar to shorthand outlines ‚Äì appear above the word ‚Äúalleluia‚Äù on the document, a vellum manuscript leaf from a Latin sacramentary, a Catholic liturgical book used in western Europe during mass from the mid- to late 800s.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Ninth-century manuscript for Easter services remained ‚Äòout of sight‚Äô for years in hands of private collector
Researchers in [Pennsylvania](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/pennsylvania) have uncovered what they believe are some of the earliest written notes in western musical history ‚Äì on a ninth-century manuscript they say remained ‚Äúhidden in plain sight‚Äù for years in the hands of a private collector.
The notations ‚Äì characters and dots similar to shorthand outlines ‚Äì appear above the word ‚Äúalleluia‚Äù on [the document](https://www.raabcollection.com/medieval-manuscripts/earliest-musical-notations), a vellum manuscript leaf from a Latin sacramentary, a [Catholic](https://www.theguardian.com/world/catholicism) liturgical book used in western [Europe](https://www.theguardian.com/world/europe-news) during mass from the mid- to late 800s.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/28/pennsylvania-historic-latin-music)

item.title: Trump demanded trans issues be excluded from sex education. 11 states complied
item.description:
Sixteen other states have sued the White House over the program, saying it‚Äôs trampling on Congress‚Äôs authority

  • US politics live ‚Äì latest updates

At least 11 states and two territories are capitulating to a recent demand from the Trump administration to strip references to gender identity and the existence of transgender and non-binary people from a federal sex education program, officials confirmed to the Guardian.

The administration set a Monday deadline to remove the references or risk losing millions of dollars of federal funding. Almost all of the states that are complying have Republican-controlled state legislatures and most have Republican governors.

Continue reading...

At least 11 states and two territories are capitulating to a recent demand from the [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) to strip references to gender identity and the existence of [transgender](https://www.theguardian.com/society/transgender) and non-binary people from a federal sex education program, officials confirmed to the Guardian.
The administration set a Monday deadline to remove the references or risk losing millions of dollars of federal funding. Almost all of the states that arecomplying have Republican-controlled state legislatures and most have [Republican](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/republicans) governors.

item.description:

Bill Gates has called for a ‚Äústrategic pivot‚Äù in the effort against the climate crisis, writing that the world should shift away from trying to limit rising temperatures to instead focusing on efforts to prevent disease and poverty.

Writing on his Gates Notes website, the billionaire Microsoft co-founder criticized what he described as a ‚Äúdoomsday view of climate change‚Äù which is focusing ‚Äútoo much on near-term emissions goals‚Äù.

item.description:

Sleeping with a passport by your pillow. Bringing a birth certificate to soccer practice. Avoiding large gatherings and crowds. Grocery shopping for relatives too afraid to go outside.

These are some of the ways that US citizens and permanent residents of color have altered how they move through the world as widespread immigration raids create a pervasive climate of fear.

item.title: What a homeowners insurance bill of rights could do
item.description: More than half of homeowners say their insurance premiums went up in the last year, according to Consumer Reports. The biggest culprits? Inflation, construction costs, and extreme weather. In response, Consumer Reports has drawn up what it calls a "Homeowners Insurance Bill of Rights," which it hopes will be adopted by states around the country. Today, we'll hear more. But first, Elon Musk has released an artificial intelligence-powered rival to Wikipedia.

item.description:
Tyler Avalos allegedly posted a video with crosshairs over Bondi‚Äôs face and a $45,000 reward for her death, FBI says

A man from Minnesota with a history of convictions has been arrested and faces federal charges for allegedly using social media to threaten the US attorney general, Pam Bondi, by suggesting he would pay $45,000 for her death.

According to an FBI affidavit viewed by the Guardian, Tyler Maxon Avalos posted a TikTok video featuring a photo of Bondi with a ‚Äúsniper scope red dot‚Äù on her forehead, with text reading: ‚ÄúWANTED: Pam Bondi. REWARD: 45,000. DEAD OR ALIVE (PREFERABLY DEAD).‚Äù

Continue reading...

item.title: $54m to walk: getting fired as a college football coach is a booming industry
item.description:
Brian Kelly‚Äôs departure from LSU is just the latest in a series of big money firings. It‚Äôs also a jarring state of affairs for many struggling fans

At a time when millions are at risk of going hungry and losing their medical insurance benefits, struggling Americans can at least take solace in knowing that the nation‚Äôs college football coaches are doing just fine ‚Äì especially Brian Kelly.

On Sunday LSU relieved Kelly of his coaching duties after his Tigers suffered a resounding home loss to Texas A&M that dropped them out of the AP‚Äôs ranking of college football‚Äôs top 25 teams. (This is after LSU was ranked as high as third in September and firmly in the top 10 for most of the season.) Kelly, who was in the fourth year of a decade-long contract worth about $100m, will be going home with more than just a box full of purple and gold office trinkets.

Continue reading...

item.title: Director of Nevada council addressing impaired driving issues charged with DUI
item.description:
Arrest of criminal justice council‚Äôs Linsey LaMontagne comes as 277 people have died on Nevada roads in 2025

The director of a committee in Nevada tasked with solving criminal justice issues including aspects of DUI arrests now faces a charge of driving under the influence herself.

Linsey LaMontagne, the director of the Clark County Criminal Justice Coordinating Council (CJCC), which covers the area encompassing Las Vegas, was arrested by a Nevada state police highway patrol trooper last April, the investigations team at the local TV news station KLAS revealed on Monday.

Continue reading...

item.title: NFL: behind the scenes at the International Series in London
item.description:
Six NFL teams played in London this month. The players were so jet-lagged they barely knew what day it was but they loved the experience

It‚Äôs 6.30pm on Sunday evening and LA Rams quarterback Matthew Stafford is speaking to reporters in an unpleasant-smelling makeshift press room in Wembley Stadium when he is interrupted by a booming voice from behind a curtain. It‚Äôs teammate Davante Adams shouting ‚ÄúWhose house?‚Äù in delight after his three touchdowns in the romp over Jacksonville Jaguars.

Adams knows what it means to score a hat-trick at Wembley but he is less certain about what day it is. ‚ÄúI feel like I‚Äôm connected to the country and the people now,‚Äù he says. With the game kicking off at 6.30am back home on the west coast, the Rams had taken the lead before most of their fans had settled on the sofa with their morning coffee. Adams and his teammates will soon be heading 5,400 miles home ‚Äì just 36 hours after arriving. Welcome to the International Series.

Continue reading...

item.title: First Thing: Humanity has missed 1.5C climate target, says UN head
item.description:
Exclusive: ‚ÄòDevastating consequences‚Äô now inevitable but emissions cuts still vital, says Ant√≥nio Guterres in sole interview before Cop30. Plus, lonely and unwell people are turning to AI chatbots for health advice

Good morning.

Humanity has failed to limit global heating to 1.5C and must change course immediately, the secretary general of the UN has warned.

What does the UN say about world‚Äôs climate plans? Recently drafted climate plans from scores of countries fall drastically short of what is needed to stave off the worst effects of climate breakdown, analysis has shown.

What do forecasters predict? Some parts of eastern Jamaica could receive up to a metre (40in) of rain while western Haiti could get 40cm (16in), the US National Hurricane Center said. ‚ÄúCatastrophic flash flooding and numerous landslides are likely.‚Äù

This is a developing story. Follow our blog here.

Continue reading...

Good morning.
Humanity has failed to limit global heating to 1.5C and must change course immediately, [the secretary general of the UN has warned](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2025/oct/28/change-course-now-humanity-has-missed-15c-climate-target-says-un-head).
**What does the UN say about world‚Äôs climate plans?** Recently drafted climate plans from scores of countries fall drastically short of what is needed to stave off the worst effects of climate breakdown, [analysis has shown](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2025/oct/28/worlds-climate-plans-fall-drastically-short-of-action-needed-analysis-shows).
**What do forecasters predict?** Some parts of eastern Jamaica could receive up to a metre (40in) of rain while western Haiti could get 40cm (16in), the US National Hurricane Center said. ‚ÄúCatastrophic flash flooding and numerous landslides are likely.‚Äù
**This is a developing story.** [Follow our blog here](https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2025/oct/28/hurricane-melissa-live-updates-category-5-storm-jamaica-landfall-latest-news).

item.title: House Republicans revive Biden ‚Äòautopen‚Äô claims in new report
item.description:
Report offers no proof of wrongdoing but repeats disputed claims about Biden‚Äôs awareness of decisions in office

US House Republicans on Tuesday unveiled their long-promised report on Joe Biden‚Äôs use of the autopen during his presidency, largely rehashing public information while criticizing his time in office and making sweeping accusations about the workings of his White House.

The Republicans‚Äô report does not include any concrete evidence that aides conspired to enact policies without Biden‚Äôs knowledge or that he was unaware of laws, pardons or executive orders signed in his name. Nonetheless, Republicans maintained their findings cast doubt on Biden‚Äôs actions in office. And they sent a letter to Pam Bondi, the attorney general, urging a full investigation ‚Äì after Donald Trump had previously ordered a similar inquiry.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Report offers no proof of wrongdoing but repeats disputed claims about Biden‚Äôs awareness of decisions in office
US House Republicans on Tuesday unveiled their long-promised report on [Joe Biden](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/joebiden)‚Äôs use of the autopen during his presidency, largely rehashing public information while criticizing his time in office and making sweeping accusations about the workings of his White House.
The [Republicans](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/republicans)‚Äô report does not include any concrete evidence that aides conspired to enact policies without Biden‚Äôs knowledge or that he was unaware of laws, pardons or executive orders signed in his name. Nonetheless, Republicans maintained their findings cast doubt on Biden‚Äôs actions in office. And they sent a letter to Pam Bondi, the attorney general, urging a full investigation ‚Äì after Donald Trump had [previously ordered a similar inquiry](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/jun/05/joe-biden-dismisses-donald-trump-inquiry-into-his-cognitive-decline-as-a-distraction).

item.title: Haitians helped boost Springfield‚Äôs economy ‚Äì now they‚Äôre fleeing in fear of Trump
item.description:
Ohio city‚Äôs economic fortunes spiral and local businesses suffer as Haitians leave due to administration‚Äôs anti-immigrant rhetoric and policies

Every morning, Alicia Mercado makes the 50-minute drive from her home in Columbus to Springfield, where she runs the Adasa Latin Market store. She opened the business next to a Haitian restaurant in 2023, having spotted a gap in the market for Caribbean and Latin foods ‚Äì the neighborhood‚Äôs Haitian population was booming at the time.

But over the past year, she says her business, which includes an international money transfer kiosk, has taken a major hit.

Continue reading...

item.title: Ben & Jerry‚Äôs owner stopped brand developing flavour for peace in Gaza
item.description:
Exclusive: Co-founder accuses ice-cream brand‚Äôs parent of taking part in ‚Äòcorporate butt kissing‚Äô of Donald Trump

The co-founder of Ben & Jerry‚Äôs has accused its owner of being part of a movement of ‚Äúcorporate butt kissing‚Äù of Donald Trump and says management blocked the ice-cream brand from producing a flavour in support of peace in Gaza.

Ben Cohen told the Guardian that Unilever was pursuing a ‚Äúcorporate attack on free speech‚Äù by blocking the development of a special flavour in solidarity with the Palestinian people. It is understood the flavour had been approved by Ben & Jerry‚Äôs independent board and first mooted about a year ago.

Continue reading...

item.title: Does the central bank have enough data to go off of?
item.description: The Federal Reserve‚Äôs Open Market Committee starts a two-day meeting on interest rates today. Most of the government data the Fed usually considers when voting on rates isn‚Äôt available because of the shutdown. We did get a tardy consumer price index report last Friday, though, and the Fed also produces some data itself. But can that paint a clear enough economic picture? Also: why workplace insurance premiums are likely to climb.

item.title: Arctic fossil is northern-most rhino species ever found

item.title: HSBC warns it could take years to settle Madoff case as bank takes $1.1bn hit
item.description:
Lawsuit over Ponzi scheme drags on London-headquartered lender, whose profits plunge by 14%

  • Business live ‚Äì latest updates

HSBC has warned it could take years to finally settle a lawsuit over the Bernard Madoff Ponzi scheme, as the bank‚Äôs profits fell 14% after it took a $1.1bn (¬£830m) hit on the 2009 scandal.

The London-headquartered bank‚Äôs finance chief issued the warning as the provision for the case dragged on HSBC profits, offsetting a jump in income in the three months to the end of September.

item.title: Atlanta journalist says he ‚Äòwon‚Äôt be the only‚Äô one deported by Trump officials
item.description:
Emmy award-winner Mario Guevara warns administration ‚Äòhas the power‚Äô after he was arrested and sent to El Salvador

Mario Guevara has said he may have been ‚Äúthe first‚Äù immigrant journalist whom Donald Trump‚Äôs administration deported from the US while working ‚Äì but the Emmy award-winner added: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think [I‚Äôll] be the only one.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust be careful because [immigration agents are] very aggressive,‚Äù Guevara recently said from El Salvador in a virtual interview with the US Press Freedom Tracker, during which he was asked whether he had any message for other immigrant colleagues in the industry. ‚ÄúThey showed they are ‚Äì they don‚Äôt care about journalists. They don‚Äôt believe in the media.‚Äù

Continue reading...

Mario Guevara has said he may have been ‚Äúthe first‚Äù immigrant journalist whom Donald Trump‚Äôs administration [deported](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/03/journalist-mario-guevara-ice-deportation) from the US while working ‚Äì but the Emmy award-winner added: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think \[I‚Äôll\] be the only one.‚Äù

item.title: Wikipedia co-founder: Trust and empathy are essential
item.description:
In his new book, Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales writes ‚Äùin the early years of the internet, we were right to be bullish about people and the technology. Our capacity for social connection, community and cooperation can deliver amazing things. But the very same human nature can deliver atrocities.‚Äù


Wales‚Äôs says he wrote this book to help combat a crisis of trust in society that is leading to the rise of authoritarianism. Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo asked him about the main lessons he learned from building Wikipedia into a highly-relied-upon source of information.
item.source:markdown:
In his new book, Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales writes ‚Äùin the early years of the internet, we were right to be bullish about people and the technology. Our capacity for social connection, community and cooperation can deliver amazing things. But the very same human nature can deliver atrocities.‚Äù
Wales‚Äôs says he wrote this book to help combat a crisis of trust in society that is leading to the rise of authoritarianism. Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo asked him about the main lessons he learned from building Wikipedia into a highly-relied-upon source of information.

item.title: ‚ÄòDrugs quieted my inner loathing‚Äô: Todd Marinovich on the NFL, addiction and the power of art
item.description:
The former Raiders quarterback‚Äôs career was shortened by off-field issues. In his new book, he looks back at a complicated life

Marcus Allen knew, and tried to help. So did Howie Long. But many of Todd Marinovich‚Äôs teammates on the Los Angeles Raiders of the early 1990s had no idea their young quarterback was using drugs.

Marinovich had come to the Raiders from USC, where he had guided the Trojans to a Rose Bowl victory as a freshman. By that time, he had accumulated two nicknames: ‚ÄúRobo Quarterback,‚Äù after the legendarily demanding training regimen instilled by his father, former Raiders player and assistant coach Marv Marinovich, intended to foster excellence in athletes. The other nickname was far more unflattering: ‚ÄúMarijuana-vich,‚Äù for his pot-smoking, which became a taunt from opposing fans in high school. When Marinovich reached the NFL, it wasn‚Äôt just marijuana he was abusing.

Continue reading...

item.title: AI 'hallucinations' could prove real problem for owner of fire-ravaged Vancouver property

item.title: Freeman‚Äôs walk-off homer lifts Dodgers over Blue Jays in 18-inning World Series epic
item.description:
• Dodgers win in 18, tying longest World Series game

  • Ohtani reaches base postseason-record nine times

  • LA lead 2-1 in series ahead of Tuesday‚Äôs Game 4

It took Freddie Freeman three chances to get it just right.

When the Los Angeles Dodgers first baseman drove a fastball deep into centerfield in the bottom of the 13th inning, the home fans at Dodger Stadium groaned as the ball nestled into Toronto Blue Jays centerfielder Daulton Varsho‚Äôs glove to make Game 3 of the 2025 World Series just the fifth World Series game to ever reach the 14th inning. Two innings later, Freeman hit the ball even harder, but not quite high enough as Varsho chased it down before it could reach the centerfield wall. The two teams were now playing the second-longest World Series game of all-time.

Continue reading...

item.title: Lionel Messi says MLS must loosen spending rules in order to thrive
item.description:
• Inter Miami star delivered remarks in an NBC interview

  • Messi reiterated his desire to play in the 2026 World Cup

Lionel Messi said that MLS must loosen its spending restrictions in order to become a top league in the world of soccer and said that he is hopeful that he will be physically able to contribute to Argentina at next summer‚Äôs World Cup.

In a rare interview with an American outlet, Messi sat down with NBC Nightly News anchor Tom Llamas at Chase Stadium in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. In the interview, Messi was asked if he felt that soccer could become as popular in the US as American sports like football, baseball, and basketball. Messi said he thinks the sport could get there, but that teams need to have more freedom first.

Continue reading...

item.title: An inside look at how London, Ont., police go from seizing illegal guns to finding out how they got here
item.description: With the number of reported shootings in London, Ont., reaching 20 in 2025, the police service says it's working tirelessly to pinpoint where illegal firearms are coming from and take them off the streets. item.title: Trump and Xi talks: what will be on the agenda when US president meets China‚Äôs leader?
item.description:
Talks on Thursday will centre on tariffs as Trump seeks to end a bruising trade war with Beijing, while Taiwan and Russia are also likely to be discussed

Donald Trump is scheduled to meet China‚Äôs Xi Jinping in South Korea this week for high stakes talks amid a bruising trade war and tense geopolitical backdrop.

Trump is expected to meet Xi on the sidelines of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit on Thursday on the final day of his Asia visit, which includes stops in Malaysia and Japan.

Continue reading...

item.title: Trump says he would be allowed to run for third term as vice-president ‚Äì video
item.description:
Donald Trump has given conflicting answers to whether he will attempt to run for a third term in 2028. At first he said he hadn't really thought about it, but then went on to say he would be allowed to run as vice-president in 2028 if he wanted to. When pressed by a reporter asking whether he would rule out running for a third term, he said cryptically: ‚ÄòI mean you'll have to tell me.‚Äô Later in the interview, however, he said he would rule out running as vice-president, saying: 'I think it's too cute. I think the people wouldn't like that'

  • Trump comments about a third term spark concern ‚Äì US politics live

  • A third term for Trump would be unconstitutional. Here‚Äôs why

item.title: Trump news at a glance: president floats a third term as Democrats vow ‚Äòno way in hell‚Äô
item.description:
President has not definitively ruled out seeking to extend time in office. Key US politics stories from Monday 27 October at a glance

  • A third term for Trump would be unconstitutional. Here‚Äôs why

Donald Trump has declined to definitively say he will not seek an unconstitutional third term as US president. ‚ÄúI would love to do it: I have my best numbers ever,‚Äù the 79-year-old told reporters on Air Force One during a trip to Asia. Pressed on whether he was not ruling out a third term, he said, ‚ÄúAm I not ruling it out? I mean, you‚Äôll have to tell me.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not the first time the president has openly expressed interest in finding a way to stay in power beyond the two terms allowed in the US constitution. But his remarks on Monday provided more details into some MAGA minds‚Äô thought process about how to pull it off.

Continue reading...

item.title: A sluggish spin cycle
item.description:
The shutdown has delayed October's durable goods report. But fear not! Michigan-based appliance manufacturer Whirlpool reported earnings today, and they were pretty tepid. What does that tell us about Trump's tariffs, or the housing market? In this episode, corporate earnings act as a stand-in for missing federal data. Plus: There are winners and losers during a period of high beef prices, small business owners scrutinize their staffing strategies, and regional banks consolidate to compete with fintech.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.


Marketplace is more than a radio show. Check out our original reporting and financial literacy content at¬†marketplace.org¬†‚Äî and consider¬†making an investment¬†in our future.

item.title: Trump officials ask supreme court to allow firing of top copyright official
item.description:
White House‚Äôs latest appeal comes after ruling that Shira Perlmutter cannot be unilaterally fired

The Trump administration on Monday asked the supreme court to allow it to fire the director of the US Copyright Office.

The administration‚Äôs newest emergency appeal to the high court was filed a month and a half after a federal appeals court in Washington held that the official, Shira Perlmutter, could not be unilaterally fired.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
White House‚Äôs latest appeal comes after ruling that Shira Perlmutter cannot be unilaterally fired
The [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) on Monday asked the [supreme court](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-supreme-court) to allow it to fire the director of the US Copyright Office.
The administration‚Äôs newest emergency appeal to the high court was filed a month and a half after a federal appeals court in Washington held that the official, Shira Perlmutter, could not be unilaterally [fired](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/may/12/trump-fires-copyright-office-shira-perlmutter).
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/27/trump-administration-supreme-court-firing-copyright-office)

item.title: New Yorkers sue state elections board as battle over House maps intensifies
item.description:
Lawsuit alleges congressional map illegally dilutes voting power of Black and Latino residents of Staten Island

A group of New Yorkers has filed a lawsuit against the state‚Äôs board of elections alleging that its congressional map unconstitutionally dilutes the voting power of Black and Latino residents of Staten Island.

The complaint, filed on Monday, is another volley in the battle between Democrats and Republicans to redraw congressional districts in a way that favors their party in advance of the midterm elections.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Lawsuit alleges congressional map illegally dilutes voting power of Black and Latino residents of Staten Island
A group of New Yorkers has filed a lawsuit against the state‚Äôs board of elections alleging that its congressional map unconstitutionally dilutes the voting power of Black and Latino residents of Staten Island.
[The complaint](https://www.democracydocket.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/2025-10-27-Petition.pdf), filed on Monday, is another volley in the battle between Democrats and Republicans to redraw congressional districts in a way that favors their party in advance of the midterm elections.

item.title: Trump comments about a third term spark concern ‚Äì as it happened
item.description:
This live blog is now closed

As Republican states launch more redistricting efforts, Democrats in blue states are still deciding how or if they will respond.

House minority leader Hakeem Jeffries is said to be headed to Illinois today to meet with local leaders about redrawing the congressional maps. Punchbowl reports that Jeffries will meet with the Illinois Legislative Black caucus and Black members of Congress, a nod to the fact that Black lawmakers will be needed to pass a new map.

Continue reading...

item.title: First banker jailed over Libor interest rate rigging to sue UBS for $400m
item.description:
Tom Hayes claims he was ‚Äòhand-picked scapegoat‚Äô for the Swiss bank as it tried to avoid regulatory scrutiny

Tom Hayes, the first banker jailed over Libor interest rate rigging, is suing his former employer UBS for $400m (¬£300m), claiming he was a ‚Äúhand-picked scapegoat‚Äù for the Swiss bank as it tried to avoid regulatory scrutiny.

The claim, which was publicly filed in a US court in Connecticut on Monday, alleges that UBS misled US authorities and called him an ‚Äúevil mastermind‚Äù behind the alleged Libor scandal, in order to protect senior executives and minimise fines.

Continue reading...

The claim, which was publicly filed in a US court in Connecticut on Monday, alleges that UBS misled US authorities and called him an ‚Äúevil mastermind‚Äù behind the alleged Libor scandal, in order to protect senior executives and minimise fines.

item.title: Former NFL MVP Adrian Peterson in jail over DWI and weapon charges
item.description:
• 40-year-old was arrested on Sunday in Texas

  • Peterson was arrested on separate DWI charge in April

Former NFL running back Adrian Peterson remained jailed on Monday after being arrested a day earlier in a Houston suburb on charges of driving while intoxicated and unlawfully carrying a weapon, according to authorities.

Peterson was taken into custody Sunday morning by the Sugar Land Police Department, said agency spokeswoman Alicia Alaniz. It‚Äôs the second DWI arrest in seven months for the 2012 NFL MVP and three-time league rushing champion.

Continue reading...

item.title: NBA memo reveals league concerned about its integrity amid gambling allegations
item.description:
• Memo comes after arrests of two prominent figures

  • Betting has caused issues across US sports

The NBA, in reaction to the arrests of Miami guard Terry Rozier and Portland coach Chauncey Billups last week for their alleged role in gambling schemes, has started a review of how the league can protect not just the integrity of the game but its players and coaches as well.

The league made those revelations in a memo sent to all 30 teams, a copy of which was obtained by the Associated Press.

Continue reading...

- Betting has caused issues across US sports

The league made those revelations in a memo sent to all 30 teams, a copy of which was obtained by the Associated Press.

item.title: Grizzly killed through Alberta‚Äôs new hunting program, province says
item.description: The Alberta government says one grizzly bear has been killed by a member of the Wildlife Management Responder Network, marking the first bear "lethally removed" since that program was implemented last summer.
item.source:markdown:
![A grizzly bear in Jasper National Park.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1.7543087,1761529741437/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28495%2C360%2C2381%2C1339%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The Alberta government says one grizzly bear has been killed by a member of the Wildlife Management Responder Network, marking the first bear "lethally removed" since that program was implemented last summer.

item.title: Javier Milei hails ‚Äòtipping point‚Äô as his far-right party wins Argentina‚Äôs midterm elections
item.description:
Result falls short of giving Milei a congressional majority but surprises many analysts after series of scandals

The party of Argentina‚Äôs far-right president, Javier Milei, has won Sunday‚Äôs midterm elections after a campaign in which Donald Trump announced a $40bn bailout for the country and made continued aid conditional on the victory of his Argentinian counterpart.

With more than 99% of ballots counted, La Libertad Avanza secured 40.8% of the nationwide vote, in an election widely seen as a de facto referendum on the self-styled anarcho-capitalist‚Äôs nearly two years in power. The Peronist opposition, Fuerza Patria, secured 31.7%.

Continue reading...

With more than 99% of ballots counted, La Libertad Avanza secured 40.8% of the nationwide vote, in an election widely seen as a de facto referendum on the [self-styled anarcho-capitalist‚Äôs](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/20/who-is-javier-milei-argentina-new-president-far-right-what-does-he-stand-for) nearly two years in power. item.title: Exxon sues California over climate laws, alleging free speech violations
item.description:
Oil firm asks court to block enforcement of laws that would require disclosure of planet-heating carbon emissions

Exxon, an oil firm consistently ranked among the world‚Äôs top contributors to global carbon emissions, is suing the state of California over two climate-focused state laws, arguing that the rules infringe upon the corporation‚Äôs right to free speech.

The 2023 laws, known collectively as the California Climate Accountability Package, will require large companies doing business in the state to disclose both their planet-heating carbon emissions and their climate-related financial risks, or face annual penalties.

Continue reading...

The 2023 laws, known collectively as the California Climate Accountability Package, will require large companies doing business in the state to disclose both their planet-heating carbon emissions and their climate-related financial risks, or face annual penalties.

item.title: The shutdown's about to get very real
item.description: The federal shutdown is already having intense effects on unpaid federal workers. But we could be approaching a tipping point. In a memo, the USDA says about 42 million people will not get their SNAP benefits, starting Saturday. We'll hear more. Also, even if we don't get an inflation report, consumers are still pinched by rising prices. And, will Canada's transportation systems be ready for the FIFA World Cup next year?

item.title: Republican Indiana governor calls special session to redraw congressional maps
item.description:
GOP-led state is latest that Trump administration has put pressure on to undertake redistricting to favor Republicans

The Indiana governor, Mike Braun, announced on Monday that he is calling a special session to consider redrawing congressional districts in the state, the latest state to work on its maps ahead of 2026.

Indiana is one of several Republican-led states the Trump administration has pressured to undertake mid-decade redistricting to favor Republicans, which began with a push in Texas to redraw lines to add Republican seats.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
GOP-led state is latest that Trump administration has put pressure on to undertake redistricting to favor Republicans
The [Indiana](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/indiana) governor, Mike Braun, announced on Monday that he is calling a special session to consider redrawing congressional districts in the state, the latest state to work on its maps ahead of 2026.
Indiana is one of several Republican-led states the [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) has pressured to undertake mid-decade redistricting to favor Republicans, which began with a push in Texas to redraw lines to add Republican seats.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/27/indiana-congressional-maps-redisctricting-governor)

item.title: Leader of top federal worker union calls for end of US government shutdown
item.description:
Hundreds of thousands of employees remain unpaid as second-longest US shutdown stretches into fourth week

The head of America‚Äôs largest federal workers union says it is time to end the government shutdown, now the second-longest in US history, as hundreds of thousands of employees miss another round of paychecks.

Everett Kelley, who leads the American Federation of Government Employees representing more than 800,000 workers, avoided assigning blame to either party in the Monday morning letter but said lawmakers must stop playing politics and pass a stopgap funding measure to reopen the government, its closure now eclipsing the four-week mark.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Hundreds of thousands of employees remain unpaid as second-longest US shutdown stretches into fourth week
The head of America‚Äôs largest federal workers union says it is time to end the [government shutdown](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/us-federal-government-shutdown-2025), now the second-longest in US history, as hundreds of thousands of employees [miss another round of paychecks](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/25/federal-workers-government-shutdown-pay-anxiety).
Everett Kelley, who leads the American Federation of Government Employees representing more than 800,000 workers, avoided assigning blame to either party in the Monday morning letter but said lawmakers must stop playing politics and pass a stopgap funding measure to reopen the government, its closure now eclipsing the four-week mark.

item.title: US transportation secretary says he‚Äôll revoke $160m from California over non-citizen truck licenses
item.description:
Sean Duffy says state is illegally issuing commercial driver‚Äôs licenses, but DMV spokesperson says California is complying with law

Sean Duffy, the US transportation secretary, warned on Sunday that he was about make good on a threat to revoke millions in federal funds for California because he says the state is illegally issuing commercial driver‚Äôs licenses to non-citizens.

In an appearance on Fox News Channel‚Äôs Sunday Morning Futures, Duffy said Gavin Newsom, California‚Äôs governor, had refused to comply with Department of Transportation rules that require the state to stop issuing such licenses and review those already issued.

Continue reading...

item.title: US debt set to soar above Italy and Greece after Trump‚Äôs ‚Äòbig, beautiful bill‚Äô
item.description:
While the European countries have brought their spending under control, the US president‚Äôs tax cuts and defence spending will lead to increased borrowing

Donald Trump is on course to push US debt levels above those of Italy and Greece by the end of the decade after wide-ranging tax cuts and increased defence spending, according to International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasts.

Illustrating the rising debt levels in Washington and efforts made by Rome and Athens to bring spending under control after the 2008 financial crash and Covid-19 pandemic, the IMF predicts the US will see its debts climb from 125% to 143% of annual income by 2030, while Italy‚Äôs will flatline at about 137%.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
While the European countries have brought their spending under control, the US president‚Äôs tax cuts and defence spending will lead to increased borrowing
Donald Trump is on course to push [US debt levels above those of Italy and Greece](https://www.imf.org/external/datamapper/GGXWDG_NGDP@WEO/OEMDC/ADVEC/WEOWORLD/ITA/USA/GRC/GBR) by the end of the decade after wide-ranging tax cuts and increased [defence spending](https://www.cfr.org/expert-brief/will-trumps-big-beautiful-defense-spending-last), according to International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasts.
Illustrating the rising debt levels in Washington and efforts made by Rome and Athens to bring spending under control after the 2008 financial crash and Covid-19 pandemic, the IMF predicts the US will see its debts climb from 125% to 143% of annual income by 2030, while Italy‚Äôs will flatline at about 137%.

item.title: NCAA must pay $18m over alleged failure to warn player about concussion risks
item.description:
• Jury finds college sports‚Äô governing body negligent

  • Robert Geathers has shown signs of CTE

A South Carolina jury has decided the NCAA owes a former college football player and his wife $18m, while finding college sports‚Äô major governing body negligent in failing to warn the player about the long-term effects of concussions.

Following a civil trial that wrapped up late last week, Orangeburg county jurors awarded $10m to 68-year-old Robert Geathers, who played at South Carolina State University from 1977 to 1980 as a defensive end. His wife, Debra, was awarded $8m, according to a court document.

Continue reading...

- Robert Geathers has shown signs of CTE

item.title: Trump ‚Äòwould love‚Äô unconstitutional third term but rules out running for VP
item.description:
Presidents are constitutionally limited to two elected terms but some had suggested unorthodox gambit to stay in office

  • US politics ‚Äì live updates

Donald Trump said on Monday morning that he would rule out running for the vice-presidency in the 2028 US election, an unorthodox approach that some of his supporters have floated to allow the Republican US president to serve a third term in the White House.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd be allowed to do that,‚Äù Trump said, in an exchange with reporters aboard Air Force One while traveling from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, the latest leg of a five-day trip to Asia which he hopes to cap with an agreement on a trade war truce with the Chinese president, Xi Jinping.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Presidents are constitutionally limited to two elected terms but some had suggested unorthodox gambit to stay in office
- [US politics ‚Äì live updates](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/oct/27/donald-trump-japan-sanae-takaichi-asia-canada-trade-news-updates-us-politics-live)
[Donald Trump](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump) said on Monday morning that he would rule out running for the vice-presidency in the 2028 US election, an unorthodox approach that some of his supporters have floated to allow the Republican US president to serve a third term in the White House.
‚ÄúI‚Äôd be allowed to do that,‚Äù Trump said, in an exchange with reporters aboard Air Force One while traveling from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, the latest leg of a five-day trip to Asia which he hopes to cap with an agreement on a [trade war truce](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/27/us-china-framework-trade-deal-xi-trump-meeting) with the Chinese president, [Xi Jinping](https://www.theguardian.com/world/xi-jinping).
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/27/donald-trump-third-term-vice-president)

item.title: Why people see tariff-induced inflation differently
item.description: Price increases are price increases, and consumers will bemoan inflation no matter the cause, right? Maybe not so much. Research shows that consumers tend to view inflation brought on by tariffs in a different light. Today, University of Chicago economist Alex Imas joins the program and uses behavioral economics to help make sense of it. But first, Louisiana will be building the first ‚Äúrare earths separation facility‚Äù in the U.S.

item.title: Trump cuts probably hindered warning process for Alaska storm that displaced hundreds, experts say
item.description:
Reductions in weather balloon launches could have degraded forecasts that residents depend on to prepare

A faltering federal response to one of the worst storms in Alaska‚Äôs history, which caused hundreds of people to become homeless, is drawing further scrutiny over the Trump administration‚Äôs efforts to dismantle federal weather and climate protections.

The powerful remnants of Typhoon Halong hit remote communities in the Yukon-Kuskokwim delta of south-west Alaska on 12 October, inundating a vast low-lying area of tundra that is home to some of the most remote and inaccessible communities in the country.

Continue reading...

item.title: US and China agree ‚Äòframework‚Äô for trade deal ahead of Xi-Trump meeting | First Thing
item.description:
US treasury secretary anticipates tariff truce with China will be extended, and that Beijing will revive substantial purchases of US soybeans. Plus, is Wikipedia‚Äôs Jimmy Wales the last decent tech baron?

  • Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

The US and China have agreed a framework for a trade deal only days before Donald Trump and the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, are due to meet.

What about other trade deals that are still up in the air? There were hopes of a truce between the US and Brazil after what President Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva described as a positive meeting with Trump in Malaysia. He said their respective teams would start discussing tariffs and other matters ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù.

And Canada? Trump said Saturday that he would raise US tariffs by 10% in retaliation for an advertisement sponsored by the Ontario government that accurately quoted Ronald Reagan at length saying tariffs don‚Äôt work.

How many people have been killed in the airstrikes? US forces in recent weeks have carried out at least eight strikes against boats in the Caribbean off Venezuela‚Äôs coast, killing about 40 people that the Trump administration has insisted were involved in smuggling drugs.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
US treasury secretary anticipates tariff truce with China will be extended, and that Beijing will revive substantial purchases of US soybeans. Plus, is Wikipedia‚Äôs Jimmy Wales the last decent tech baron?
- [**Don‚Äôt already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here**](https://www.theguardian.com/info/2018/sep/17/guardian-us-morning-briefing-sign-up-to-stay-informed)
Good morning.
The US and China have [agreed a framework for a trade deal](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/27/us-china-framework-trade-deal-xi-trump-meeting) only days before Donald Trump and the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, are due to meet.
**What about other trade deals that are still up in the air?** There were hopes of a truce between the US and Brazil after what President Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva described as a positive meeting with Trump in Malaysia. He said their respective teams would start discussing tariffs and other matters ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù.
**And Canada?** Trump said Saturday that he would [raise US tariffs by 10%](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/25/trump-tariffs-canada-ronald-reagan) in retaliation for an [advertisement](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/24/trump-canada-trade-negotations-ontario-tariffs) sponsored by the Ontario government that accurately quoted Ronald Reagan at length saying tariffs don‚Äôt work.
**How many people have been killed in the airstrikes?** US forces in recent weeks have carried out at least eight strikes against boats in the Caribbean off Venezuela‚Äôs coast, killing about 40 people that the Trump administration has insisted were involved in smuggling drugs.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/27/first-thing-us-and-china-agree-framework-for-trade-deal-ahead-of-xi-trump-meeting)

item.title: Southeast Asian countries strike trade deals with U.S.
item.description: From the BBC World Service: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations summit is underway in Malaysia. So far, Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Malaysia have all struck a series of trade agreements with President Donald Trump. Then, the party of Argentinian President Javier Milei saw major wins in Sunday's midterm elections, despite widespread discontent with deep austerity measures. And we'll learn about preparations for next summer‚Äôs FIFA World Cup, which will be hosted jointly by the U.S., Canada, and Mexico in 16 different cities.
item.source:markdown: _From the BBC World Service:_ The Association of Southeast Asian Nations summit is underway in Malaysia. So far, Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Malaysia have all struck a series of trade agreements with President Donald Trump. Then, the party of Argentinian President Javier Milei saw major wins in Sunday's midterm elections, despite widespread discontent with deep austerity measures. And we'll learn about preparations for next summer‚Äôs FIFA World Cup, which will be hosted jointly by the U.S., Canada, and Mexico in 16 different cities.

item.title: The old man and the mirror: Aaron Rodgers meets the quarterback he used to be
item.description:
The four-time MVP faced his old team on Sunday night and put in a respectable performance. But it was Jordan Love who was able to control the game

It all started so well. And then it fell apart.

For two quarters, it looked like Aaron Rodgers might conjure one of those nights, the sort that ends with a smirk, a wink, and a reminder that he can match any of the league‚Äôs young pups. It was the first time in his career that he played against Green Bay, where he spent nearly two decades, won four MVPs and a lone Super Bowl. But the NFL rarely cares for nostalgia.

Continue reading...

item.title: Sites marketed as tools for catching infidelity can also be misused by stalkers
item.description:
There are a lot of trending videos of people using face recognition tools to find cheating partners on dating apps. On TikTok, for example, videos have gone viral about people explaining how to use the tools like Cheater Buster, plus other staged videos of supposed partners catching their significant other on Tinder.


Joseph Cox, tech reporter at 404 Media, looked into the sudden rise of these services and the risks they pose to privacy.

item.title: Republican senator calls Trump‚Äôs military airstrikes ‚Äòextrajudicial killings‚Äô
item.description:
Rand Paul‚Äôs comments come days after president claimed US lawmakers wouldn‚Äôt take issue with Venezuelan strikes

  • Exclusive: CIA playing ‚Äòmost important part‚Äô in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources say

The Trump administration‚Äôs military airstrikes against boats off Venezuela‚Äôs coast that the White House claims were being used for drug trafficking are ‚Äúextrajudicial killings‚Äù, said Rand Paul, the president‚Äôs fellow Republican and US senator from Kentucky.

Paul‚Äôs strong comments on the topic came on Sunday during an interview on Republican-friendly Fox News, three days after Donald Trump publicly claimed he ‚Äúcan‚Äôt imagine‚Äù federal lawmakers would have ‚Äúany problem‚Äù with the strikes when asked about seeking congressional approval for them.

Continue reading...

item.title: Some Canadian communities make it mandatory for homeowners to replace lead pipes. Do such bylaws work?
item.description: The Canadian Environmental Law Association is recommending that all cities pass bylaws to make it mandatory for property owners to replace lead pipes on their side of the property line. Hamilton has a bylaw aimed at preventing partial lead service-line replacements, and some Quebec and Saskatchewan have similar rules. Here's what people in Thunder Bay, Ont., have to say about the idea as the city faces a $350-million class-action lawsuit.
item.source:markdown:
![A close-up of a lead pipe being held outside.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/8055da9e-c298-4366-a466-2de9dbcb1752,1761340616194/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C635%2C357%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The Canadian Environmental Law Association is recommending that all cities pass bylaws to make it mandatory for property owners to replace lead pipes on their side of the property line. Hamilton has a bylaw aimed at preventing partial lead service-line replacements, and some Quebec and Saskatchewan have similar rules. Here's what people in Thunder Bay, Ont., have to say about the idea as the city faces a $350-million class-action lawsuit.

item.title: LSU fire Brian Kelly with coach owed more than $50m in buyout clause
item.description:
• Tigers lost heavily to Texas A&M at home

  • Louisiana governor weighed in on struggles

Less than four years after being hired away from Notre Dame, Brian Kelly has been fired by LSU, the school‚Äôs athletic director, Scott Woodward, announced on Sunday night.

‚ÄúWhen Coach Kelly arrived at LSU four years ago, we had high hopes that he would lead us to multiple SEC and national championships during his time in Baton Rouge,‚Äù Woodward said. ‚ÄúUltimately, the success at the level that LSU demands simply did not materialize.‚Äù

item.title: NFL week eight: Broncos crush Cowboys, Colts defeat Titans, and more ‚Äì as it happened
item.description:
Denver Broncos scored over 40 points against the Dallas Cowboys while the New York Jets won their first game of the season

Panthers 0-6 Bills 14:09, 2nd quarter

It‚Äôs good! But Carolina come out on top as Buffalo settle for a field goal. Josh Allen successfully scrambles around once but on the second effort is sacked on 3rd and 5. Not the end of the world but a cheap penalty forced Allen to put on his dancing shoes after an illegal formation penalty. Matt Prater knocks in the 43-yard field goal.

Continue reading...

item.title: ICE detains British journalist after criticism of Israel on US tour
item.description:
Trump ally Laura Loomer took credit for Sami Hamdi‚Äôs detainment in move denounced as ‚Äòaffront to free speech‚Äô

The British journalist Sami Hamdi was reportedly detained on Sunday morning by federal immigration authorities at San Francisco international airport, and the Council on American-Islamic Relations (Cair) says that action is apparent retaliation for the Muslim political commentator‚Äôs criticism of Israel while touring the US.

A statement from Cair said it was ‚Äúa blatant affront to free speech‚Äù to detain Hamdi for criticizing Israel‚Äôs ongoing military campaign in Gaza while he engaged on a speaking tour in the US. A Trump administration official added in a separate statement that Hamdi was facing deportation.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Trump ally Laura Loomer took credit for Sami Hamdi‚Äôs detainment in move denounced as ‚Äòaffront to free speech‚Äô
The British journalist [Sami Hamdi](https://x.com/SALHACHIMI/status/1920429867071365310?t=IZFPhDZHDqy6sA3yvbhRfA&s=19) was reportedly detained on Sunday morning by federal immigration authorities at [San Francisco](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/san-francisco) international airport, and the Council on American-Islamic Relations (Cair) says that action is apparent retaliation for the Muslim [political commentator](https://x.com/SALHACHIMI/status/1920429867071365310?t=IZFPhDZHDqy6sA3yvbhRfA&s=19)‚Äôs criticism of Israel while touring the US.
A [statement](https://www.cair.com/press_releases/breaking-cair-calls-on-ice-to-release-sami-hamdi-british-journalist-abducted-over-criticism-of-israels-genocide/) from Cair said it was ‚Äúa blatant affront to free speech‚Äù to detain Hamdi for criticizing Israel‚Äôs ongoing military campaign in Gaza while he engaged on a speaking tour in the US. A [Trump administration](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trump-administration) official added in a separate statement that Hamdi was facing deportation.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/26/ice-detains-british-muslim-journalist-laura-loomer)

item.title: Gavin Newsom confirms he is considering 2028 presidential run
item.description:
Democratic California governor and high-profile Trump critic plans to make decision after 2026 midterms

Gavin Newsom, California‚Äôs Democratic governor, told CBS News Sunday Morning he planned to make a decision on whether to run for president in 2028 once the 2026 midterm elections are over.

‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôd be lying otherwise,‚Äù Newsom said in response to a question on whether he would give serious thought to a White House bid after the 2026 elections. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd just be lying. And I‚Äôm not ‚Äì I can‚Äôt do that.‚Äù

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
Democratic California governor and high-profile Trump critic plans to make decision after 2026 midterms
[Gavin Newsom](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/gavin-newsom), [California](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/california)‚Äôs Democratic governor, [told](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/newsom-says-he-will-consider-white-house-run-after-2026-elections/?linkId=872056531) CBS News Sunday Morning he planned to make a decision on whether to run for president in 2028 once the 2026 midterm elections are over.
‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôd be lying otherwise,‚Äù Newsom said in response to a question on whether he would give serious thought to a White House bid after the 2026 elections. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd just be lying. And I‚Äôm not ‚Äì I can‚Äôt do that.‚Äù
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/26/gavin-newsom-2028-presidential-race)

item.title: What‚Äôs in a name? Sask. town looking to find out by selling naming rights to highest bidder
item.description: The small Saskatchewan town of Duck Lake could soon bear a new name, after its council voted to move forward with putting the town's permanent naming rights up for sale. Mayor Jason Anderson says he's hoping corporations or anyone willing to pay a minimum of $10 million will see the value of putting their mark on the map.

item.title: Not everyone‚Äôs stretching the dollar the same way
item.description:
Consumers everywhere are trying to stretch their dollars to compensate for economic uncertainty and inflation. However, there‚Äôs a divide between higher and lower earners. In this episode, we look at how people across the economic spectrum are trying to get more bang for their buck. Plus, one recent college graduate‚Äôs decision to leave the U.S. for job prospects abroad, commodity shortages mean less chocolate in your Halloween candy, and a weekly wrap-up of the latest economic headlines.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.


Marketplace is more than a radio show. Check out our original reporting and financial literacy content at¬†marketplace.org¬†‚Äî and consider¬†making an investment¬†in our future.

item.title: Inuit leader replaced amid allegations of abuse
item.description: The Manitoba Inuit Association has appointed an interim CEO, as a petition with more than 1,200 signatures circulates calling on the non-profit organization to look into allegations of sexual and physical abuse against its CEO, Nastania Mullin. It‚Äôs part of what some are calling an #InuitMeToo grassroots campaign.
item.source:markdown:
![The Manitoba Inuit Association has appointed an interim CEO amidst allegations of abuse and calls to investigate its current leader.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b9107cf7-f7f2-482b-b7ea-f20e7695fa63,1761351444403/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C378%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Chicago vs. ICE
item.description:
Chicago has been dealing with a lot these days. The city has been a battleground for the Trump administration‚Äôs immigration crackdown and efforts to deploy the National Guard. On today‚Äôs show, Kimberly asks WBEZ‚Äôs Sasha-Ann Simons about what it‚Äôs like to be there now. And, we‚Äôll get into more economic stories from the Windy City you should know about. Plus, we‚Äôll play a game of Half Full/Half Empty!


Here‚Äôs everything we talked about today:


  • "ICE Is Cracking Down on Chicago. Some Chicagoans Are Fighting Back." from The New York Times
  • "Local leaders react to ‚Äòbrutal escalation‚Äô of immigration arrests in Little Village, Cicero" from WBEZ
  • "Judge‚Äôs order blocking National Guard deployment will remain in effect for now, but all eyes on Supreme Court" from WBEZ
  • "Coca-Cola taps mini cans and new flavors to spark a fizzling soda market" from Marketplace
  • "‚ÄòIt‚Äôs PR, not the ER‚Äô: Gen Z is resisting the workplace emergency" The Washington Post
  • "Netflix‚Äôs ‚ÄòStranger Things‚Äô Series Finale Officially Coming to Theaters, Despite Previous Statements" from The Hollywood Reporter
  • "Amazon Plans to Replace More Than Half a Million Jobs With Robots" from The New York Times¬†


We love hearing from you. Leave us a voicemail at 508-U-B-SMART or email makemesmart@marketplace.org.

item.title: Webequie First Nation wraps up public review period on Ring of Fire supply road project
item.description: Webequie First Nation has completed the public review for the proposed 107-kilometre Webequie Supply Road. Once built, the two-lane, all-season road would connect the fly-in community to future mineral exploration zones in the Ring of Fire region.

item.title: Getting down to the nuts and bolts of the trade war
item.description: Small businesses are feeling the squeeze as tariffs and material costs climb. Rob Lehmann is the founder of Fair Wind Fasteners, a supplier of nuts, bolts, and screws. He explains how fluctuating import costs and trade policies are reshaping his operations. From sourcing metal to keeping prices steady for customers, we hear a firsthand view of what it takes to stay afloat in a volatile economy. Plus: President Trump said he is ending trade negotiations with Canada pardoned the founder of the Binance cryptocurrency exchange.

item.title: US prices rose at a 3% annual rate in September, slightly beating forecasts
item.description:
Increase was largely driven by a 4.1% increase in gasoline prices despite Trump‚Äôs campaign pledge to ‚Äòend inflation‚Äô

Prices continued to rise in September, increasing at an annual rate of 3%, according to the latest government inflation report.

The September 2025 consumer price index (CPI) was published approximately two weeks later than usual due to the federal government shutdown, which halted all Bureau of Labor Statistics operations.

Continue reading...

Increase was largely driven by a 4.1% increase in gasoline prices despite Trump‚Äôs campaign pledge to ‚Äòend inflation‚Äô

item.title: President Trump axes trade talks with Canada
item.description: From the BBC World Service: President Donald Trump has abruptly cut off all trade talks with America‚Äôs northern neighbor. Trump was responding to an anti-tariff ad paid for by the province of Ontario, which featured a clip of former President Ronald Reagan speaking negatively about tariffs. About three-quarters of Canada's exports go to the U.S.; many now face a 35% Levy. Plus, it‚Äôs been a turbulent week for gold prices, but what‚Äôs causing the recent downturn?

item.title: The NBA jumped into bed with gambling. Now the league is getting its due
item.description:
The arrests of a prominent coach and player on Thursday were depressing but it is hard to have sympathy with a league that has embraced gambling

The NBA scoreboard has turned into a stock ticker. Crowd chants, but half of them are watching their parlays instead of the play. Somewhere a coach calls timeout; somewhere else a bookmaker grins. This was always coming. The NBA invited gambling to the game when it signed lucrative sponsorship deals and paved the way for odds and offers to be splashed over our TV screens during games. So when the FBI finally showed up on Thursday, they were simply collecting the rent.

Portland head coach Chauncey Billups, whose playing career ended with his induction in the hall of fame, and Miami guard Terry Rozier were arrested Thursday in connection with an FBI investigation into allegations of illegal gambling and rigged poker games. Former player and assistant coach Damon Jones, who allegedly provided ‚Äúinside information‚Äù about NBA games to bettors, was also taken into custody.

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
The arrests of a prominent coach and player on Thursday were depressing but it is hard to have sympathy with a league that has embraced gambling
The NBA scoreboard has turned into a stock ticker. Crowd chants, but half of them are watching their parlays instead of the play. Somewhere a coach calls timeout; somewhere else a bookmaker grins. This was always coming. The NBA invited gambling to the game when it signed lucrative sponsorship deals and paved the way for odds and offers to be splashed over our TV screens during games. So when the FBI finally showed up on Thursday, they were simply collecting the rent.
Portland head coach Chauncey Billups, whose playing career ended with his induction in the hall of fame, and Miami guard Terry Rozier [were arrested Thursday](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/oct/23/heats-rozier-and-blazers-coach-billups-reportedly-arrested-over-separate-gambling-claims) in connection with an FBI investigation into allegations of illegal gambling and rigged poker games. Former player and assistant coach Damon Jones, [who allegedly provided](https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/46700252/source-bettors-got-privileged-injury-info-lebron-james) ‚Äúinside information‚Äù about NBA games to bettors, was also taken into custody.
[Continue reading...](https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2025/oct/24/the-nba-jumped-into-bed-with-gambling-now-the-league-is-getting-its-due)

item.title: Protestors show resistance to immigration crackdown in San Francisco - video
item.description:
Donald Trump has canceled plans for a deployment of federal troops to San Francisco that had sparked widespread condemnation from California leaders and sent protestors flooding into the streets. The Bay Area region had been on edge after reports emerged the Trump administration was poised to send more than 100 Customs and Border Protection and other federal agents to the US Coast Guard base in Alameda, a city in the East Bay, as part of a large-scale immigration-enforcement plan. It prompted hundreds of protesters to mobilize outside the Coast Guard base

item.title: The national debt hit $38 trillion, and yes, you should care
item.description:
The U.S. national debt hit a new record this week: $38 trillion. As we head toward the fifth week of a government shutdown over a congressional budget disagreement, we explain why the growing national debt matters and how it affects your wallet. Also in this episode: Where does surplus oil go as demand drops? How might a wearable AI device affect your relationships? And, why are credit card companies offering more perks?


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.

item.title: How can our food systems become more sustainable?

The climate crisis has a lot to do with what we eat. That‚Äôs what the latest season of Marketplace‚Äôs climate solutions podcast ‚ÄúHow We Survive‚Äù is all about. On today‚Äôs show, host Amy Scott joins Kimberly to share her big takeaways from the season. Here‚Äôs everything we talked about today:


  • "How We Survive" from Marketplace
  • "State of Climate Action 2025" from Systems Change Lab
  • "I paid $65 for a giant collection of vintage dishes at a thrift store. Then I found out it's worth almost $1,000." from Business Insider


Join us tomorrow for ‚ÄúEconomics on Tap.‚Äù The¬†YouTube livestream¬†starts at 3:30 p.m. Pacific time, 6:30 p.m. Eastern.

item.title: Federal funds to keep the heat on this winter are stalled
item.description: As the weather gets colder, many lower-income Americans will depend on LIHEAP, a program that helps them heat their homes. Receiving LIHEAP assistance to keep the heat on was a reality for over 5 million American households in fiscal year 2024. But existing funds are running low, and future funds are stalled during the shutdown. Also: markets react to the continued federal shutdown, and the Trump administration plans to take stakes in several quantum computing companies.

item.title: 'Stupid political stunt': Vance criticises Knesset vote to annex West Bank ‚Äì¬†video
item.description:
US vice-president has criticised Israel‚Äôs parliament vote on West Bank annexation, calling the move a 'stupid political stunt' after a bill applying Israeli law to the occupied West Bank, a move tantamount to the annexation of land Palestinians want for a state, won preliminary approval from Israel‚Äôs parliament on Wednesday. Speaking on the tarmac of Tel Aviv‚Äôs international airport before departing at the end of his visit to Israel, JD Vance insisted that 'the policy of the Trump administration is that the West Bank will not be annexed by Israel. That will continue to be our policy. And if people want to take symbolic votes, they can do that but we certainly weren't happy about it,' adding:'I personally take some insult to it'

  • Marco Rubio warns Israel not to annex West Bank after Knesset vote in favour

Continue reading...
item.source:markdown:
US vice-president has criticised Israel‚Äôs parliament vote on West Bank annexation, calling the move a 'stupid political stunt' after a bill applying Israeli law to the occupied [West Bank](https://www.theguardian.com/world/west-bank), a move tantamount to the annexation of land Palestinians want for a state, won preliminary approval from Israel‚Äôs parliament on Wednesday. Speaking on the tarmac of Tel Aviv‚Äôs international airport before departing at the end of his visit to Israel, JD Vance insisted that 'the policy of the Trump administration is that the West Bank will not be annexed by Israel. That will continue to be our policy. And if people want to take symbolic votes, they can do that but we certainly weren't happy about it,' adding:'I personally take some insult to it'

item.title: Parsing the impact of fresh U.S. sanctions on Russian oil
item.description: From the BBC World Service: In an effort to pressure Moscow to negotiate a peace deal in Ukraine, the United States has announced new sanctions on Russian oil. The sanctions effectively blacklist two of Russia's major oil export companies, and that has big implications for both India and China, which rely heavily on Russian oil imports. And then recent talks to make the shipping industry greener have stalled. So what‚Äôs the industry doing to cut emissions?

item.title: How Indigenous communities are adopting AI
item.description:
Artificial intelligence holds a lot of promise for tribal nations ‚Äî as a force multiplier for hard-to-staff departments, a tool to better serve tribal citizens, and even to aid in the revitalization of Indigenous languages and culture.


But, as with all applications of AI tools, data security concerns loom. And some nations are adopting the new technology quicker than others. For an overview, Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo spoke with Savannah Peters, who covers Indigenous communities for Marketplace.

item.title: Federal funding pullbacks in JD Vance's hometown
item.description: The Trump administration has moved to axe many Biden-era green initiatives. One project impacted is in Middletown, Ohio ‚Äî¬†the hometown of Vice President JD Vance. Environmentalists had hoped that the conversion of a steel plant there from coal to hydrogen-powered furnaces could be a blueprint for future eco-friendly upgrades, but that project has been canceled. Also on the show: collective bargaining rights for Uber and Lyft drivers in California and a U.S.-Australia alliance concerning rare earth metals.
item.source:markdown: The Trump administration has moved to axe many Biden-era green initiatives. One project impacted is in Middletown, Ohio ‚Äî¬†the hometown of Vice President JD Vance. item.title: Call it a silver squeeze
item.description: Silver hit an all-time high last week. Helping fuel that rally is a physical shortage; global demand for silver has been outstripping supply since 2020. We'll hear about the supply of silver, which has more industrial uses than its flashier cousin, gold. Also, a Brazilian oil giant will start drilling near the mouth of the Amazon River. And coming soon to a convenience store near you: individual mini Coke cans.

item.title: Auditor general blasts Indigenous Services Canada for failing to improve essential programs

item.title: Record stocks welcome Japan‚Äôs first female prime minister
item.description: From the BBC World Service: Japan elected its first female prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, and the Nikkei 225 index surged to a record high. But the conservative leader,¬†who models herself after former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, will have to tackle a range of economic challenges: a falling population, a rise in the cost of living, and sluggish growth. Plus, a federal green tech funding pullback in the U.S. is hitting Vice President JD Vance‚Äôs hometown.

item.title: How's that BLS data coming along?
item.description:
Our picture of the U.S. economy grows fuzzier each day the government shutdown continues. The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which publishes the most reliable economic data, has been a barebones operation since the shutdown began. In this episode, how this month‚Äôs data from the public and private sectors may be affected. Plus: Recruiters give mixed takes on the job market, oil services companies are up against low prices and a supply glut, and streaming platforms set their sights on video games and podcasts.


Every story has an economic angle. Want some in your inbox?¬†Subscribe¬†to our daily or weekly newsletter.

item.title: Climate adaptation as part of the curriculum
item.description: Agriculture is notoriously susceptible to the whims of the elements. Farmers and ranchers can see their entire livelihoods turn on one bad hailstorm or ill-timed heat wave, which are more frequent as our planet continues to warm. Today, we'll head to Colorado to hear about an apprenticeship program that's embedding climate literacy into its teachings. But first: the value of the dollar, this morning's web outages, and pain for small- and mid-sized businesses.
item.source:markdown: Agriculture is notoriously susceptible to the whims of the elements. item.title: When a cloud service that powers much of the internet goes down
item.description: There's been a major outage of Amazon Web Services, the Amazon system that does computing for other companies. The list of impacted sites and platforms is lengthy: Facebook, Snapchat, Reddit, Fortnite, Lyft, McDonald's, Robinhood, and Amazon itself, to name a few. We'll hear more. Plus, altcoins are poised to take a step into the financial mainstream, and China plans its economic future as it deals with tariff fallout and slowing economic growth.

item.title: China's leaders meet to draw up an economic blueprint

And as Diwali ‚Äî¬†the Hindu festival of light ‚Äî begins, we'll ask how consumers in India are dealing with the rising price of gold, which is central to gift-giving there.

item.title: New CA law requires Uber and Lyft to bargain with drivers
item.description:
California has enacted a law requiring rideshare giants Uber and Lyft to collectively bargain with their drivers. Because the drivers are technically independent contractors, they otherwise would not have federally-protected labor rights like full-time employees. The new state law could be a game changer.


Marketplace‚Äôs Nova Safo spoke with Levi Sumagaysay, reporter at CalMatters, who helps sift through the details of the law.
